userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Rochambeau Papers and Rochambeau Family Cartographic Archive is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Rochambeau Papers and Rochambeau Family Cartographic Archive. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This finding aid was derived from a much more lengthy document received with the collection, which presumably was prepared at the donor's request. That list was converted into an ASCII data file by means of scanning and Optical Character Recognition software, and then a number of format and editorial changes were made to achieve a finding aid which is more in accordance with current Beinecke Library practice. Specifically, lengthy narratives and notes containing biographical data, excerpts from the letters or the Mémoires , and historical commentary were removed or abbreviated. Punctuation in bibliographical descriptions, however, was retained. Names of correspondents have been standardized. The source document from which the present list was derived has been retained, however, and may be viewed both in print form and online, upon consultation with the appropriate curator.

bioghist.head: JEAN-BAPTISTE DONATIEN DE VIMEUR, COMTE DE ROCHAMBEAU (1725-1807)
bioghist.p: The comte de Rochambeau was born at Vendôme in 1725 and began his long military career at age sixteen. He distinguished himself early on, serving in both the War of the Austrian Succession and the Seven Years' War. He was promoted to the rank of maréchal de camp and inspector of cavalry in 1761, and in 1776 he was appointed governor of Villefranche-en-Roussillon. In 1780, Rochambeau assumed the direction of the French expeditionary force sent by Louis XVI to assist the American colonists in their war of independence. He landed at Newport, Rhode Island, and a year later joined Washington's Army at the Hudson River. From there the combined French and Continental forces marched to Virginia to besiege Yorktown. With Washington, he planned the colonial victory at Yorktown, leading to the British surrender that ended the American Revolution.

After the British defeat, Rochambeau returned to France and continued his military service through the early years of the French Revolution. After a short imprisonment during the Terror, Rochambeau returned to his family's château near Vendôme where he remained in retirement for most of the rest of his life. During these later years, he wrote his Mémoires Militaires, Historiques et Politiques , which were published posthumously in 1809.

For a more extensive biographical essay and description of the comte de Rochambeau's life as it relates specifically to the content of this archive, consult "The Road to Yorktown" (New Haven: Yale University Library, 1992), an exhibit catalog prepared by Vincent Giroud, Curator of Modern Books and Manuscripts, for a special exhibition of material from the Rochambeau Papers and Rochambeau Family Cartographic Archive at the Beinecke Library.

bioghist.head: JOSEPH-CHARLES DE VIMEUR, MARQUIS DE ROCHAMBEAU (d. 1779)
bioghist.p: Joseph-Charles de Vimeur, marquis de Rochambeau, was the father of the comte de Rochambeau. Due to ill health he was unable to pursue an active military career. Nevertheless, in 1723 he was appointed grand bailli d'épée of the duchy of Vendômois and governor of the château, and in 1728 was named governor of the town of Vendôme. As Knight of the Order of Saint-Lazare and of Saint-Sépulcre de Jérusalem, he was chosen to represent the tribunal of the marshals of France in his province. He died at Vendôme on December 19, 1779.

bioghist.head: DONATIEN MARIE JOSEPH DE VIMEUR, VICOMTE DE ROCHAMBEAU (1755-1813)
bioghist.p: Donatien Marie Joseph de Vimeur, vicomte de Rochambeau, served in the American Revolution as an aide-de-camp to his father. In the 1790s he participated in an unsuccessful campaign to establish French authority in Martinique and Santo Domingo. He was later assigned to the Italian army, and was appointed to the military command of the Ligurian Republic. In 1802, he was chosen to help lead an (unsuccessful) expeditionary force against Santo Domingo. He was captured by the English and returned to England as a prisoner on parole, where he remained interned for almost nine years. He was exchanged in 1811, and returned to the family château, where he resumed the work of classifying the family's growing collection of maps, which his father had begun. He also enriched the collections with new acquisitions, in particular ones pertaining to the military campaigns of his son, Auguste-Philippe Donatien de Vimeur, who served as the aide-de-camp for Joachim Murat, maréchal de France (and brother-in-law of Napoleon) and was with Murat's cavalry in the Russian campaign.
In 1812 the vicomte de Rochambeau was recalled to active service. On October 16, 1813, he was mortally wounded in the "Battle of Nations," and died three days later at Leipzig, at the age of 59.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Rochambeau Papers and Rochambeau Family Cartographic Archive is divided into two parts, the Rochambeau Papers, and the Cartographic Archive. The Rochambeau Papers consist of the correspondence and other documents of the comte de Rochambeau that document his role as commander of the French expeditionary force in the American Revolution. The papers also include the manuscript draft of his memoir, Mémoires Militaires, Historiques et Politiques. The Cartographic Archive consists of atlases and maps collected by three generations of the Rochambeau family, from the reign of Louis XIV through the wars of the French Revolution and the Empire. It includes maps acquired by the comte de Rochambeau before he departed for America, and which he used in the field during the American campaign. The archive remained with the family at the chateau de Rochambeau until 1952, when it was purchased by the New York bookdealer H.P. Kraus. Paul Mellon, Yale 1929, acquired the collection from Kraus in 1958 and gave it to Yale in 1992.

Little is known about the original arrangement of the papers. All the maps, however, were systematically numbered with an "IK" classification scheme late in the 19th century by the marquis Eugène Achille Lacroix de Rochambeau. (Similar IK numbering appears on maps in the papers of Donatien Marie Joseph de Vimeur, vicomte de Rochambeau, pertaining to his service in the French West Indies, which were given to Yale by H.P. Kraus in 1968.) In all likelihood there was an original catalog to the IK series that explained the order of the IK numbers, but it's whereabouts, if it survives, are unknown and the nature of the original classification scheme has yet to be determined. The maps, when received by the library, were organized by provenance, and therein arranged more or less chronologically. This arrangement has been retained.

The first section, Correspondence and Other Documents, consists of three series: Correspondence to Rochambeau , Conference Papers and Other Documents , and Mémoires . These papers richly document Rochambeau's role as commander of the French troops in the American Revolution, from his arrival in Rhode Island to his departure for France after the battle of Yorktown, and the close working relationship which developed between Washington and his French counterpart.

Series I, Correspondence to Rochambeau
(1780-1794), is organized into six subseries: George Washington and Other Americans; Gilbert du Motier, marquis de Lafayette; French Diplomats in America; French Navy in America; French Army under Rochambeau; and The French Court. Generally, letters from the Americans to Rochambeau are in English with translations into French supplied by Rochambeau. While not all of the correspondence is addressed to Rochambeau, all of it relates to military affairs of concern to him and its presence in the archive suggests that he received it at some point. Each subseries has been arranged chronologically, except for The French Court, where it was decided that the run of letters from the marquis de Ségur be kept together and not be interfiled with other letters in the subseries.

Because Rochambeau exchanged communiqués with so many people on military matters of mutual concern, his correspondence files provide extensive coverage of the sequence of events in the American campaign, and of the roles played by various individuals. It also provides commentary on events from varying perspectives. For example, in the case of the interception by the British of George Washington's letter to Lund Washington criticizing the French, one finds Washington's letter of apology (folder 68), the letter of La Luzerne, the French Minister Plenipotentiary, transcribing Washington's letter for Rochambeau, and dismissing it as harmless (folder 154), and the letter of Ségur, the French Minister of War, expressing his satisfaction that the letter had caused no bad feelings (folder 244).

Of the 77 Washington letters in the collection, eleven of them are autograph letters signed, while the rest were written by secretaries (including Alexander Hamilton) and signed by Washington. The majority of Washington's letters cover the period from Rochambeau's arrival in Rhode Island in July 1780 to August 1781, when their armies converged on the march to Yorktown. Washington writes of troop movements and plans, the treason of Benedict Arnold and capture of Major André, the mutiny of the Pennsylvania line of the Army, apologizes for his letter to Lund Washington, and discusses the logistics of the arrival of de Grasse. In a final letter, written upon his return to Mount Vernon after the war, Washington reflected on his collaboration with Rochambeau: "I shall recollect with pleasure that we have been Contemporaries & fellow labourers in the cause of liberty, and that we have lived together as Brothers do - in harmony & friendship."

Early drafts of all of the Washington letters present in the archive are represented in John C. Fitzpatrick's Writings of Washington . Documentation received with the collection indicates that some of the letters found in this collection differ from those in Fitzpatrick. Notations to this effect, present in the list from which this finding aid was derived, have been retained though not verified. Other American correspondents in this series include Thomas McKean, Nathaniel Greene, Jonathan Trumbull, John Tyler, Benjamin Tallmadge, and Henry Knox.

The correspondence of Gilbert du Motier, marquis de Lafayette, consists of 14 letters written between May and September, 1780, before Washington's first letter to Rochambeau, while Lafayette was serving as Washington and Rochambeau's liaison. It includes a letter of apology from Lafayette to Rochambeau (folder 111), for overstepping his authority as liaison, which led to direct communication between Washington and Rochambeau.

The third section, French Diplomats in America, includes 62 letters from La Luzerne, the French minister plenipotentiary, and the comte de Menonville, who was in charge of gathering supplies for the French. This correspondence, covering the period from June 1780 to December 1781, encompasses discussions of the much delayed second fleet, and the financing of the French campaign. Four additional letters, from the comte de Menonville, also concern supplies.

The next subseries, French Navy in America, consists chiefly of 23 letters from Admiral de Grasse, written from March to October 1781 and during the Yorktown campaign. There are also letters from key officers who accompanied Rochambeau from France: Admiral Barras (11 letters), Destouches (3 letters), and a letter written by Washington to Admiral Ternay, first commander of the French fleet (folder 184). This section contains the letter from Admiral de Grasse written July 28 which states that he will sail to Virginia with his fleet, estimates when he will arrive, and warns that he cannot stay past October (folder 187), a letter which marks the beginning of the military campaign that resulted in the battle of Yorktown. Many of the letters are partly in code, often with an interlinear decipher.

The section entitled French Army under Rochambeau contains five letters from the marquis de Choisy, who was left in charge of the small force at Newport after Rochambeau and most of the army had departed for Yorktown. Correspondence from members of the French Court includes 39 letters from Ségur, the French Minister of War, written from January-December 1781 with two letters in April and May, 1784. Ségur sends orders, bestows praise for Rochambeau's conduct, and in 1784 commissions him commander-in-chief of Picardy. There are also six letters from the marquis de Castries, Minister of the Navy.

Series II, Conference Papers and Other Documents
, contains material that pertains to several war strategy conferences held between Rochambeau and Washington. These include the Wethersfield Conference (May 13-23, 1781), the Newport Conferences (May 31 and June 8, 1781), the Dobbs Ferry Conference (July 1781), and the Philadelphia Conference (July 1782). Except for the Newport Conference, the files contain drafts of propositions and resolutions on double columned pages with one side written by Rochambeau and the other by Washington. The Newport papers are summaries of the Conferences signed by Grandchain de Semonville, Captain of the Newport fleet.

The section of Other Documents contains orders, field notes, and narratives by Rochambeau of French army activity in 1781-1783. There are five manuscripts detailing the ciphers and codes used by the Americans and the French, with various other documents which include intercepted letters from Lord George Germain to Sir Henry Clinton in February-March 1781.

Series III contains the manuscript of Rochambeau's
Mémoires Militaires, Historiques et Politiques
, published posthumously in Paris in 1809. The Mémoires detail Rochambeau's entire career, and includes some elaboration of events mentioned in the correspondence. The original division of the manuscript into notebooks ("cahiers") has been maintained. The manuscript is written on 307 leaves in Rochambeau's hand and that of several others, with glosses and editorial work, also by Rochambeau. The manuscript contains a large amount of material cancelled by the author and either omitted entirely or abridged in the final published form. Some of the cancelled passages include criticisms of French officers, a description of Rochambeau's life at the time of his arrest and imprisonment in 1794, and a description of a dinner given by him for Washington at Newport.

The Cartographic Archive is organized into four series: Map Collection of the Marquis de Rochambeau , the Map Collection of the Comte de Rochambeau , the Map Collection of the Vicomte de Rochambeau , and Other Rochambeau Maps . The subseries within each series are organized roughly in chronological order. The maps within the subseries themselves, however, are arranged in no particular order, as they were received.

Virtually every map in the collection carries an affixed map tab bearing the IK number and a short title word or phrase indicating the place depicted on the map. Each map entry in the register consists of this short (assigned) title prefaced by the original IK number, with place, mapmaker and/or publisher, and date noted, if known. The full title and other information from the source list received from Paul Mellon also have been included, with title and dimensions verified for this finding aid. The full map titles have been transcribed exactly as found on the maps; no attempt has been made to standardize forms of names and spellings.

Most of the maps in this collection are in sections and backed on linen. Some of these were grouped in cardboard sleeves. These groups of maps have been removed from the sleeves, foldered individually and filed in sequence, and are gathered together in the finding aid under one unifying assigned title. The sleeves themselves have been retained and are housed and listed at the end of the collection. Not all maps are complete, and some are duplicates. These have been noted in the listing. A majority of the maps are hand-colored.

Series IV, the Map Collection of the Marquis de Rochambeau
(1669-1743), is organized into two subseries: the War of the Austrian Succession and Miscellaneous Maps. This series, consisting of 19 maps, includes regional maps, city maps, and battle plans, and contains the earliest dated maps in the collection. Information received with the collection attributes acquisition of certain maritime maps in this series to the Chevalier de Rochambeau, chef d'escadre, uncle of the marquis, although it does not identify them.

Series V, the Map Collection of the Comte de Rochambeau
(1695-1792), is organized into ten subseries: War of the Austrian Succession (Bohemian and Bavarian Campaigns, and Low Countries Campaign), Cantons of Franche-Comté and Campaign Against Mandrin, Seven Years' War (Minorca Campaign, and German Campaign), Inspector-General of Infantry, Plan to Invade England, American Revolution, Command of Picardy and Artois, Command of Alsace, Journey to Switzerland, and Army of the North: Brabant Campaign.

The 360 maps in this series span the comte de Rochambeau's entire military career. There are maps of varying types: regional maps, city maps, and maps commemorating battles (many were certainly used by Rochambeau in the field). Mapmakers represented prominently include Le Rouge; Johann Baptist Homann, and his heirs, known as Homann Erben; Eugene Henry Friex; Georges Friex; Alexis Hubert Jaillot; Pierre Gosse, Jr. and Daniel Pinet; Matthaeus Seutter; and Carlet de la Rozière. There are several larger maps printed in sections, particularly in the American Revolution subseries. In these cases, the maps share one title, followed by a description of each part.

A number of maps bear annotations in Rochambeau's hand. In particular, there is a map of Lawfeld (folder 678) on which he marked the place where he was seriously wounded. Rochambeau also annotated: Partie du Piemont (folder 828), Plan des Attaques de Maestricht (folder 682), Carte des Environs de Liège, Mastrick (folder 838), and Le Cours du Rhein (folder 689).

The German Campaign section of the Seven Years' War subseries contains four maps with tipped on overlays showing troop movements. These are: Plan de la Bataille de Creveld (folder 715), Plan des Affaires de Sangershausen et de Lutternberg (folder 855), Plan de la Bataille de Tonhausen (folder 856), Plan de la Bataille de Vellinghausen (folder 857), and Plan de l'Affaire de Soest (folder 897). In addition, there are 4 watercolor manuscript maps: Cherbourg (folder 876), Plan de Luxembourg (folder 781), Plan de Strasbourg (folder 901), Neuf Brisack (folder 782), and Huningue (folder 783).

The American Revolution subseries includes 103 maps of the Atlantic coast and major harbors, general maps of North America, maps of various colonies, cities, and Canada. A portfolio of large linen-backed maps (folders 631-644) duplicates many of the maps elsewhere in the series. Scattered other duplicates and even triplicates can also be found.

A highlight of the series is a manuscript atlas of 34 plans in ink and watercolor of the camps of Rochambeau's army as he marched south to Yorktown (folder 455). The plans are very detailed, and are attributed to Louis-Alexandre and Charles-Louis Berthier. There are two additional atlases: one is a second volume of an atlas with no title page, but a table of contents that states it is the second part of the Nouvel Atlas (folder 630). The other atlas is of the Antilles (folder 645). All these atlases, while retained in the archive, have also been cataloged separately. Another unusual item is a proof of a presumably unfinished plate of the Coast of North America by Sartine, probably acquired by Rochambeau before leaving Europe for Rhode Island (folder 392).

Series VI, the Map Collection of the Vicomte de Rochambeau
(1702-1823), is organized into eight subseries: American Islands, Italian Campaign and Command of Liguria, Prisoner in England, Central European Campaigns, French and European Campaigns, Spanish and Portuguese Campaigns, Russian Campaign, and German Campaign.

The 184 maps in this series are regional maps mainly of Europe and the West Indies, city maps, road maps, maps of battlefields and military campaigns. It should be noted that there are a small number of duplicates in this series as well. There is a large map of the United States (folders 468-471), and a relatively large number of Italian maps. Mapmakers represented in this series include Le Rouge, Cassini, Santini, and Dezauche. There are three atlases in this series, a little volume entitled Guide to the Post-Roads of Italy (folder 646), also Cary's New Map of England and Wales (folder 647), and an unbound atlas of Livonia in parts (folders 597-605). There is also a map of Spain with stick pins that indicate Napoleon's march on Madrid (folder 595).
Series VII, Other Rochambeau Maps (1755), contains two maps whose precise provenance is unknown. Series VIII, Index (n.d.), contains an inventory of the map collection.

did.unittitle: Correspondence to Rochambeau

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I, Correspondence to Rochambeau , is organized into six subseries: George Washington and Other Americans; Gilbert du Motier, marquis de Lafayette; French Diplomats in America; French Navy in America; French Army Under Rochambeau; and The French Court. Unless otherwise noted, all letters are to Rochambeau.

did.unittitle: GEORGE WASHINGTON AND OTHER AMERICANS

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Unless otherwise noted, all letters are in English.

did.unittitle: Dobbs, William, and Patrick Dennis

Copy of a letter to unidentified recipient. 1 page, folio. Manuscript, "Remarks on the Navigation leading to New York, with reference to the Chart marked No. 1." 3 1/2 pages, folio. Headquarters. (Copy)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter and report by pilots acquainted with the harbor of New York. This letter and report (originally accompanied by a chart, which is not present) are copies made by Rochambeau.

did.unittitle: Washington, George
Autograph letter signed. 4 pages, folio. Headquarters in New Jersey. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 2 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Welcomes Rochambeau and the French army to America and states his confidence in the marquis de Lafayette.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 2 1/2 pages, folio. Headquarters in New Jersey. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Acknowledges receipt of dispatches from Rochambeau relating to his arrival in the country.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, folio. Headquarters. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 1/4 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News that Clinton is embarking on an expedition against the French army.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, folio. "Head Quarters near passaick falls, 10 o'Clock at night." With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, half page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Account of the British army's movements under Clinton, and their artillery strength.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. This letter is in the handwriting of Alexander Hamilton. 1 page, folio. Highlands, New York. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, half page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Advises him that Clinton has sailed with the principal part of his forces (about 8,000 men).

did.unittitle: Parsons, Samuel Holden
Autograph letter signed. 3 pages, folio. New London. With translation into French, in Rochambeau's hand- writing, of a portion of the letter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News of Clinton's abortive attempt to attack Rochambeau at Newport, with information on the strength, number of vessels, etc. in the British force, then at Huntington on Long Island.

did.unittitle: Washington, George

Letter signed. This letter is in the handwriting of Alexander Hamilton. 2 pages, folio. Headquarters. With a copy of a letter to Chevalier de La Luzerne, 1 1/2 pages, folio. Peekskill. With an autograph translation of both letters into French by Rochambeau, 3 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Military intelligence and projects, Clinton's return with his fleet to Long Island and Washington's removal to Dobbs Ferry. For the letter to La Luzerne, see: Oversize Boxes, box 41, folder 648. This letter concerns the measures to be taken in regard to the expected arrival of the second division of the French army.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, folio. "Head Quarters near Orange Town." With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau on the conjugate leaf, quarter page, folio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Expresses hope that information regarding the second division is accurate, and urges that such information be withheld from the enemy.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. This letter is in the handwriting of Alexander Hamilton. 1 1/2 pages, 4to. "Head Quarters, Orange Town." With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, half page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Information that the enemy is preparing an embarkation involving 2,000 troops, but that the destination is, as yet, unknown.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. This letter is in the handwriting of Alexander Hamilton. 3 pages, 4to. "Head quarters Orange Town." With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News concerning the navies.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. This letter is in the handwriting of Alexander Hamilton. 4 1/2 pages, 4to. "Head Quarters Orange Town." With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 4 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Proposals for an attack on New York, outlining three ways in which they might accomplish their purpose: attacking York Island, attacking Brooklyn, or dividing forces.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 3 pages, folio. "Headqrs in the vicinity of Fort Lee." With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 2 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concern about Captain Peter Landais, who had commanded the Pallas during John Paul Jones' battle with the Serapis. He also expresses concern about a report of letters being intercepted by the Tories, and encloses a letter written on the 21st that he feared was among them. (The copy mentioned is not present.)

did.unittitle: Letter signed. This letter is in the handwriting of Alexander Hamilton. 3 1/2 pages, 4to. "Head Quarters Liberty Pole in Bergen County." With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 2 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News of Clinton soliciting spies; dismissal of the principal part of the militia which were called out for three months; and a reference to a visit to Rochambeau by an Indian delegation.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, folio. Including postscript. "Head Quarters New Bridge Bergen County." With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 1/4 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News of General Gates' defeat at Camden, South Carolina, on the 16th of August, 1780. A conference is proposed for the 20th of September at Hartford. This letter has been damaged on the fore margin by an ink blot, and subsequent paper damage, affecting about 10 words of the text.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/3 pages, 4to. Headquarters, Bergen County. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A false rumor of reinforcements.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, 4to. "Head Qrs. Bergen County N[ew] Bridge." With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, half page 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Postponement of the Hartford conference until the 25th. It should be noted that the date given in The Writings of George Washington , ed. John C. Fitzpatrick, vol. 20, p. 44, is the 20th of September. See also the following letter, where the date is changed again to the 20th.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. This letter is in the handwriting of Alexander Hamilton. 2 pages, 4to. "Head Quarters New Bridge." With a manuscript intelligence report to Washington, from Philadelphia. 1 page, folio. [Philadelphia, September, 1780.] Also with an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, to which is added a translation of the enclosure, 3 1/2 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A renewal of the proposal to meet at Hartford on September 20th. The report states that Count de Guichen, with the French West Indies fleet, was supposed to be sailing for Rhode Island.

did.unittitle: Trumbull, Jonathan
Autograph letter signed. 1 1/4 pages, folio. Lebanon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerns the supply of provisions to the French army.

did.unittitle: Washington, George
Letter signed. This letter is in the handwriting of Alexander Hamilton. 1 page, 4to. Headquarters near West Point. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, half page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Informs Rochambeau of the treason of Benedict Arnold. Date changed from September 27. This letter is listed and reproduced in The American Campaigns of Rochambeau's Army 1780, 1781, 1782, 1783 , trans. and ed. by Howard C. Rice, Jr., and Anne S. K. Brown, Vol. I, p. xxvii and between pp. 240 and 241.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 3 pages, 4to. "Head Quarters Prackness." With an autograph postscript, signed with initials. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerns Major André and his execution. The postscript mentions an enclosed letter to Dr. Franklin. The present letter as printed in The Writings of George Washington , ed. by John C. Fitzpatrick, vol. 20, p. 151, does not include the postscript.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, folio. "Head Quarters Prackness." With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, half page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Military intelligence regarding an embarkation at New York.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages, folio. "Head Quarters Prackness." With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Agrees to Rochambeau's plans for winter quarters for the French army.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/4 pages, folio. "Head Quarters Prackness." With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, half page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerns military intelligence relating to the fleet forces.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, folio. "Head Quarters Prackness." With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, half page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Extends his good wishes to Rochambeau's son on his mission to France, and also relays intelligence regarding British naval movements.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, folio. Head- quarters, Passaic Falls. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, half page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerns an exchange of prisoners with Sir Henry Clinton.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, folio. "Head Quarters Prackness." With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, half page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News of British troop movements. In The Writings of George Washington , ed. John C. Fitzpatrick, vol. 20, p. 347, the place of this letter is given as Passaic Falls.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages, folio. Head- quarters, Passaic Falls. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Military intelligence relating to fleet activity.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 3 pages, folio. Headquarters, Passaic Falls. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 1/4 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Speculation that Clinton may send a reinforcement to the South from New York, and his plans for the army's winter quarters.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 1/2 pages, folio. Headquarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A description of his winter visits with his Army and the French.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, folio. Head- quarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, half page 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Intelligence from New York about an embarkation commanded by Generals Knyphausen and Phillips.

did.unittitle: Letter signed, to Rochambeau and Charles de Ternay. 7 pages, folio. New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 4 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A proposal for an expedition to the Southern States.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 3 pages, folio. New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerns the proposed reinforcements from France.

did.unittitle: Holker, John
Letter signed, in French. 7 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An explanation of some of his operations in obtaining specie in Philadelphia and New England.

did.unittitle: Washington, George
Letter signed. 3 pages, folio. Head- quarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 1/4 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Intelligence reports relating to Arnold's departure for Virginia, and news of the Spanish fleet and transports. With news of the expiration of enlistments on December 31.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, folio. Headquarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News of General Leslie's landing at Cape Fear in North Carolina.

did.unittitle: Knox, Henry
Autograph Letter signed. 4 pages, 4to. Lebanon. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 2 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Details of the mutiny of the Pennsylvania line of the American army in New Jersey.

did.unittitle: Washington, George
Letter signed. 4 pages, folio. Head- quarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 2 pages, folio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reports the end of the Pennsylvania troops mutiny, and the trip of Lt. Col. Laurens to the Court of France to negotiate finances.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. This letter is in the handwriting of Alexander Hamilton. 2 pages, 4to. Headquarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 1/4 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Account of the mutiny of the New Jersey troops.

did.unittitle: Ledyard, William
Autograph letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, folio. New London.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A report of the strong gale that had struck the British fleet in Gardiners Bay on Long Island.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, folio. New London. 8 O'Clock PM.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: More news of the damage caused by the gale.

did.unittitle: Washington, George
Autograph letter signed. 3 1/2 pages, folio. Headquarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 1/2 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The surrender of the New Jersey mutineers; the details of a battle at Westchester; the particulars regarding Benedict Arnold's raid in Virginia; the import of Leslie's imminent junction with Cornwallis; and Gen. Greene's movements in the south.

did.unittitle: Ledyard, William
Autograph letter signed. 2 pages, folio. New London. 3 O'Clock PM.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Another report on the damage to the British fleet. Ledyard updates the information relating to the ships now in Gardiners Bay.

did.unittitle: Washington, George

Letter signed. This letter is in the handwriting of Alexander Hamilton. 1 page, folio. Headquarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 page, 4to.; and with address sheet bearing the franking signature of Washington.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Acknowledges the intelligence information contained in Rochambeau's letter of Jan. 29th regarding a storm which had dispersed the British squadron blockading the French fleet in Newport.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages, folio. Head- quarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News of Morgan's victory over Tarleton at Cowpens, the defeat of a body of Tories by a Lt. Col. Washington, and plans for a visit to Newport.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 4 1/2 pages, folio. Headquarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 3 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News that he has sent 1200 men to the head of Elk River, and a discussion of Arnold's force in Virginia.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages, 4to. New Windsor. This letter is in the handwriting of Alexander Hamilton. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 1/4 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Congratulates Rochambeau on the safe arrival of his son in France, and relates a letter he received from the President of Congress. He continues with his plans regarding Benedict Arnold.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 3 1/2 pages, folio. New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 2 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A copy of his letter to Destouches in which he explains more precisely his propositions. [Letter not present.] He also discusses more fully his proposition for a detachment of land troops, and indicates his intention to march the Pennsylvania line south.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 4 pages, folio. New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 2 1/4 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: More from the South, where the marquis de Lafayette has been sent to push forward to the head of the Elk River. He also writes about Greene's battles with Cornwallis and Tarleton.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/4 pages, folio. "Colo. Morehouses." With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 page, 4to. With the franking signature of Washington, red wax seal preserved.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerns the departure of the naval expedition to the Chesapeake.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, folio. Lebanon. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News of Lafayette's intended route down the Chesapeake Bay to Virginia.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, 4to. Hartford. 5 o'clock a.m. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, half page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News from General Heath of British troop movements.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. With a signed postscript that is dated the 22d. 2 1/2 pages, folio. Headquarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 1/2 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Promises to communicate news from the Chesapeake as soon as he has it, and also mentions news of a formal declaration of war by Great Britain against the states of Holland.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, folio. Headquarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, half page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Regrets that he has no news from Virginia. He comments on the British troop movements.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages, folio. Head- quarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: States that the Minister of France has informed him of the naval action off the Cape of the Chesapeake on the 16th. He also acknowledges the receipt of an account concerning an engagement on the 15th between General Greene and Cornwallis in North Carolina.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages, folio. Head- quarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Further news of the engagement on the 15th in North Carolina between Greene and Cornwallis, with a copy of the letter from Greene giving the details of the battle [this copy not present]. He also sends the British account of the engagement that had taken place on the 16th between the fleets.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 4 pages, folio. With a postscript signed of 1 1/2 pages, folio. Together, 5 1/2 pages. Head- quarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 3 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Military plans for the coming campaign season, with instructions to Rochambeau to stay where he is until he receives news from France about the reinforcements, but to feign preparations for a departure. The post- script relates the information that the British detachment had finally sailed from the Hook about the 20th of March.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed, to Rochambeau and Admiral Destouches. 1 1/2 pages, folio. Headquarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An account via Major Benjamin Tallmadge of the British on Long Island, with the suggestion of an attack.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages, folio. Head- quarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Intelligence regarding an embarkation from New York.

did.unittitle: Wadsworth, Jeremiah
Autograph letter signed. 4 pages, 4to. Hartford.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Supplies for the march of the French army from Rhode Island.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, 4to. Hartford. Noon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: More on the supplies for the march.

did.unittitle: Washington, George
Letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, folio. Headquarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, half page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Intelligence from Major Tallmadge on Long Island about the British fleet.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, folio. Head- quarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, half page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Intelligence indicating that Admiral Arbuthnot and his fleet are in New York harbor, and that three or four ships, damaged in action, are under repair.

did.unittitle: Wadsworth, Jeremiah
Autograph letter signed. 1 page, 4to. Hartford.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerns the supply of wagons, drivers, and horses for the march.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 3 pages, 4to. Hartford.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerns supplies and the depreciation of paper money.

did.unittitle: G., S.
Copy of a letter. 2 pages, folio. New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Report of an American spy in New York on the British works there, and the British navy, the Cork Fleet and the troops of York Island, Long Island and Staten Island. In his letter to Rochambeau of May 7th, Washington mentions having sent this report to him.

did.unittitle: Washington, George
Letter signed. 2 pages, folio. Head- quarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Postpones Tallmadge's proposed raid because of the absence of light Frigates. He also mentions his conference with General de Beville about different routes from Newport to the North River. It is indicated that a paper with intelligence from Europe and the West Indies was enclosed with this letter, but it is not present.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 3 pages, folio. Headquarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 1/2 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An explanation and apology regarding a letter to his to his relative Lund Washington which had been intercepted by the British and published. A portion of the letter was critical of the French naval commander, Admiral Destouches, and was published in Rivington's Gazette April 4th.

did.unittitle: Tallmadge, Benjamin
Autograph letter signed. 4 pages, 4to. Wethersfield "2 O'Clock in the Morning." With enclosed copy of a letter from "S.C." 1 1/2 pages, folio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerns arrangements for espionage on Long Island and in New York City. The enclosed letter is signed "S.C." (Samuel Culper, the assumed name of Aaron Woodhull, of Setauket, L.I.). In it, Woodhull gives information on the British and Hessian troops stationed at Lloyd's Neck, Oyster Bay, and Herricks, N.Y.

did.unittitle: Washington, George
Letter signed. 1 2/3 pages, folio. Headquarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, half page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Refers to the mission of Col. Menonville, and the appointment of Col. Champlin as Barrack Master to the French army.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. With an autograph postscript, signed with initials. 1 1/2 pages, folio. New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, half page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Relays information contained in a letter from Col. Dayton, an intelligence officer near Elizabethtown.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, folio. Head- quarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, half page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Congratulates Rochambeau on the safe return of his son, expressing the hope that he brings good news; he states that he will meet with Rochambeau at Wethersfield at any time he wishes to appoint; and that he has had no further accounts from New York.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/4 pages, folio. Headquarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, half page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Settles the date for the conference, and says that Generals Knox and Duportail will accompany him.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 3 1/2 pages, 4to. Head- quarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 1/4 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reminds Rochambeau that the figures for the force he would be able to supply is tentative, pending approval of the States. He relates news from General Greene in South Carolina regarding his troop movements and the efforts of Lord Rawden to force Greene away from Camden.

did.unittitle: Greene, William
Autograph letter signed. 1 page, 4to. Providence. With Greene's franking signature.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Informs Rochambeau that a portion of the militia troops would be ready by the 5th of June, and sets out the arrangements for the transport of baggage from Newport to Providence.

did.unittitle: Washington, George
Letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, 4to. Headquarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, half page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News that one of his messengers had been captured between New Windsor and Morristown, and also that Lafayette has sent word that Cornwallis and Arnold have joined forces at Petersburg.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 4 pages, 4to. Head- quarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 2 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Expresses the opinion that the French fleet should leave Newport Harbor for Boston Harbor once the major portion of the French troops have left Rhode Island; he does, however, send letters to Rochambeau for the Governors of Massachusetts and Rhode Island in the event the French leaders decide to leave their fleet at Newport.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages, folio. Head- quarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 1/4 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reports that the Fleet is headed for Rhode Island, and that Rochambeau ought not leave at the moment but await reinforcements. He reports that the British are marching unopposed through Virginia, and urges Rochambeau to join him as soon as possible.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 4 pages, folio. Head- quarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 2 1/4 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Agrees to the detention of the fleet at Rhode Island, relates that the British army is between Richmond and Fredericksburg, but that their destination is uncertain. He also replies to Rochambeau's news that the French West Indies fleet under de Grasse would arrive to participate in the 1781 summer campaign. He suggests leaving it to de Grasse to choose his landing place from the news he receives before he sails. Written partially in ciphers, with an interlinear decipher. Most of the cipher in this letter is by simple substitutions; some is in a numerical code.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, folio. Headquarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Proposes a naval expedition to Chesapeake Bay, says he is sending copies of two letters from Greene regarding the successes in South Carolina (letters not present).

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 1/2 pages, 4to. With ms. enclosure, 1 page, 4to. Head- quarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Urges Rochambeau not to exhaust his troops by too rapid a march. The enclosure contains an extract of a letter from Sullivan to Washington dated in Philadelphia June 11, 1781 regarding a rumor that a fleet from England arrived in the Chesapeake the week before.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, folio. Headquarters, New Windsor. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Expresses his satisfaction with the progress of Rochambeau's march.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, folio. "Camp near Peekskill." With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Explains why he was prevented from meeting Rochambeau, expresses his pleasure that they are in agreement on the position for Rochambeau's troops, and encloses a copy of an intelligence report just received from La Luzerne.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 4 pages, folio. "Head Quarters near Peekskill." With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 2 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sets the date and explains plans for the New York raid.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 1/2 pages, folio. Headquarters, Peekskill. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 2 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: States that he doesn't have any great hope of carrying out this plan of attacking New York. With manuscript notes in Rochambeau's hand on page 4.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, 4to. Head- quarters, Peekskill. With the franking signature of Washington. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tells Rochambeau that he should proceed to North Castle where he should wait until his whole force joins him.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, 4to. "Head Quarters Valentines Hill." 8 O'Clock at Evening. With the franking signature of Washington. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, half page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Informs Rochambeau that he plans to march the next day, to White Plains and hopes that Rochambeau can meet them there.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 2/3 pages, 4to. "Camp near White plains." With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, half page 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Urges Rochambeau to give his troops an additional day's rest, before marching from North Castle to join the American army.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, folio. Chatham. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, half page, 4to. Addressed on p. 4.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Intelligence that the British have been landing troops on Staten Island. He plans to halt the American troops for one day at Springfield, and hopes that Rochambeau will stop his troops at Whippany, and reassures him that this will not delay plans for an embarkation.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, folio. Chatham. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, half page, 4to. Addressed on p. 4.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: States that the forces on Staten Island are not large, and suggests that Rochambeau march his troops in one or two Divisions. A rendezvous at Princeton is mentioned as well. This letter is listed and reproduced in The American Campaigns of Rochambeau's Army 1780, 1781, 1782, 1783 , trans. and ed. by Howard C. Rice, Jr., and Anne S. K. Brown, Vol. I, p. xvii and between pp. 60 and 61.

did.unittitle: Gist, Mordecai
Copy, "Traduction de La Lettre du Gl. Gist a S. E. le Gl. Washington," of a letter to Washington (which was written from Baltimore), translated into French. 3 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: States that de Grasse's fleet arrived in Chesapeake Bay on the 26th of August, and landed 3000 men on the 27th on the south bank of the James River. The last page of the letter is a list of the French ships.

did.unittitle: McKean, Thomas
Autograph letter signed. 1 page, 4to. Philadelphia. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, half page, narrow 12mo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The President of Congress thanks Rochambeau following the review of the French army on its march to Virginia. This letter is listed and reproduced in The American Campaigns of Rochambeau's Army 1780, 1781, 1782, 1783 , trans. and ed. by Howard C. Rice, Jr., and Anne S. K. Brown, Vol. I, p. xviii and between pages 60 and 61.

did.unittitle: Trumbull, Jonathan
Autograph letter signed. 1 page, folio. Lebanon, Conn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Congratulations on the defeat of Cornwallis.

did.unittitle: Greene, Nathaniel
Letter signed. 5 pages, 4to. "Head Quarters at the Round O." With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 1/4 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Relates his progress in the Southern states, that only Charlestown and Savannah have not fallen.

did.unittitle: Washington, George
Translation into French of a letter from Washington to Rochambeau (Philadelphia) in the handwriting of Rochambeau. Half page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: States that Congress is making vigorous preparations for the coming campaign.

did.unittitle: Tyler, John
Document signed. 1 page, folio. [Williamsburg] In the House of Delegates Monday.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The official thanks of Virginia to the French allies.

did.unittitle: Greene, Nathaniel

Autograph letter signed. 5 1/2 pages, 4to; also, an autograph note ("An Estimate of the British in, and expected at Charles Town Decembr. 23d. 1781") enclosed, 2 1/2 pages, 12mo.; together, 8 pages. "Head Quarters, round O." With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 2 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Having received intelligence regarding additional British troops on the way, he asks for reinforcements. The autograph note enclosed lists the information under the headings "In Charles Town," "Invalids," "Expected in a few days from Ireland," "from New York," and "Total Infantry."

did.unittitle: Washington, George
Letter signed. 1 page, folio. Philadelphia. With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, half page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerns news of an embarkation from New York with the possible destination of South Carolina.

did.unittitle: Baltimore, City of

Manuscript address, "To his Excellency, The Count Rochambeau, Commander in chief of the auxiliary Troops, of his most Christian Majesty, in the United States. We, the Merchants of the Town of Baltimore..." Signed by Saml Purviance, Richard Curson, Sam Smith, Mark Pringle, and Wm. Patterson. 1 1/2 pages, folio. [Baltimore.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An address expressing the thanks of the City of Baltimore for the French forces.

did.unittitle: Williamsburg, City of

Manuscript address, "To His Excellency, the Count de Rochambeau Lieutenant General of the Armies of the King of France &c &c. &c.... We the Mayor, Recorder, Aldermen, and Common Council of the City of Williamsburg..." 1 1/2 pages, folio. [Williamsburg.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Congratulates the French King on the birth of his son, and acknowledges the city's obligation to the French troops. The address is not signed.

did.unittitle: Washington, George
Autograph letter signed. 2 pages, 4to. Mount Vernon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Writes of the end of the Revolutionary War and his retirement to Mount Vernon, and states, "I shall recollect with pleasure, that we have been Contemporaries & fellow labourers in the cause of liberty, and that we have lived together as Brothers should do - in harmony & friendship." This letter differs in many details with the letter printed in The Writings of George Washington , ed. John C. Fitzpatrick, vol. 27, pp. 316-317.

did.unittitle: Randolph, Edmund J.
Autograph letter signed, to Donatien- Marie-Joseph de Vimeur, vicomte de Rochambeau. 1 page, 4to. Philadelphia. 1794 Apr 29

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In regard to an appointment to see President Washington.

did.unittitle: Smart, Thomas
Autograph letter signed, to Donatien- Marie-Joseph de Vimeur, Vicomte de Rochambeau. 1 page, 4to. With enclosure, 1 page 4to. Providence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An invitation to vicomte de Rochambeau to attend the 4th of July celebration in Providence. The enclosure is the actual invitation.

did.unittitle: GILBERT DU MOTIER, MARQUIS DE LAFAYETTE

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Unless otherwise indicated, all letters are in French.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 14 1/2 pages, folio. With autograph notes by Lafayette and Rochambeau on the first page. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A summary of the military situation in America, with details of Washington's campaign plans. This letter was written in duplicate and placed in the hands of couriers who were to wait at Cape Henry, Virginia, and Point Judith, Rhode Island, to divert Rochambeau to New York. This copy is the one sent to Point Judith, which was actually delivered to Rochambeau. Rochambeau's autograph note states, (translated), "I did not receive this letter at Rhode Island until several days after my arrival, when the enemy had concentrated in force at New York after the capture of Charleston."

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed, to Rochambeau and Ternay. 3 pages, folio. With an autograph note by Rochambeau on the first page. "Au quartier general de Morristown."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Describes several anchorages at Newport suitable for the ships, and advises him to encamp the troops on the mainland, not on Rhode Island itself. Details are given regarding the availability of supplies at Rhode Island, and communications between Rochambeau and Washington following the former's arrival. This letter awaited Rochambeau at Point Judith, Rhode Island.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 2 pages, folio. With autograph notation by Rochambeau on the first page. Frayed on edges, damaging a few words. "Sur les hauteurs de Springfield" [New Jersey].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News of the surrender of Charleston to the British, and the return of a portion of the British land and naval forces to New York.

did.unittitle: Letter signed, to Rochambeau and Ternay. 13 pages, folio. With autograph postscript by Lafayette, and notation in the autograph of Rochambeau on the first page. Preakness, N.J.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Informs them of Washington's plans for an attack on New York.

did.unittitle: Letter, to Rochambeau and Ternay. 1 1/2 pages, folio. Preakness, N.J. With enclosed copy of a letter (in English) of Elias Dayton to Washington (dated July 15, 1780), partly with interlinear translation in the autograph of Rochambeau.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Intelligence of the reappearance at New York of Admiral Graves with six battleships, and defers to Rochambeau's judgment as to whether an immediate attack on New York can be made. Two copies of this letter were sent out, to Rhode Island (this copy, the one received by Rochambeau), and to Black Point, New Jersey. Lafayette didn't sign this copy, which bears, however, the address in his handwriting.

did.unittitle: Letter signed, to Rochambeau and Ternay. 12 pages, folio. With autograph postscript by Lafayette. "Au Camp en avant de dob's Ferry."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A report of the conference between Lafayette, Rochambeau, and Ternay.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed, to Rochambeau and Ternay. 4 pages, folio. "Au Camp."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A justification for his letter of August 9th. He tells Rochambeau that the letter was, in effect, a copy of the written report that he had submitted to Washington concerning the conference, and that he thought it entirely correct to send him a copy of it; that the messages he conveyed to Rochambeau and Ternay were authorized by Washington; and that he would do all he could to persuade Washington to meet Rochambeau for a conference.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 4 pages, 4to. "Au Camp."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A personal letter of apology, sent along with his formal answer to Rochambeau of the same date.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 2 l/2 pages, 4to. "Au Camp de la division legere pres du fort lee."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An explanation of various difficulties that had arisen. Dispatches from France had arrived at Boston on the frigate Alliance , but all of them had been sent on to Washington. He tells Rochambeau that the militia troops collected for the summer operations were to be dismissed for lack of subsistence for them, and gives news of operations in Bergen County, New Jersey, and in the vicinity of Paulus Hook and Fort Lee.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 2 pages, 4to. "Light Camp."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A warning to Rochambeau that preparations were being made in New York harbor for a ship movement, with Rhode Island as a possible destination.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 2 pages, 4to. "Au Camp de la division legere."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerning preparations for the Hartford conference between Rochambeau and Washington. After referring to General Gates' disastrous defeat at Camden, he speaks again about the delay in the dispatches, and about Washington's difficulties with a letter in French from Rochambeau.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 2 pages, 4to. "Au Camp pres hakinsac." [Hackensack, N.J.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News that no dispatches have been received from the French government about the second division.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, 4to. "Au Camp pres hakinsac." [Hackensack, N.J.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A report of a troop embarkation at New York, which he believes is directed against Virginia. He also tells of the rumored arrival of Admiral de Guichen with a French fleet on the American coast.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, 4to. "Robertson's house pres Westpoint."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerns the discovery of Benedict Arnold's treason.

did.unittitle: FRENCH DIPLOMATS IN AMERICA
La Luzerne, Anne-César, chevalier de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Unless otherwise indicated, all letters from La Luzerne to Rochambeau are in French.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 3 pages, folio. With docket in Rochambeau's handwriting. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A letter written in advance of Rochambeau's arrival, giving information about the preparations which had been made, in obtaining horses and other supplies, and requesting that his responsibility for such financial dealings terminate as soon as possible.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 1/2 pages, folio. Partly in code, with interlinear decode. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Welcomes Rochambeau to America. In the coded portion of the letter he gives his opinion of the American commanders, saying that some of them are slow and apathetic, but that Rochambeau will find Washington's army stronger than he expects.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 1 1/4 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A French officer is recommended, as he was fluent in English, and in American politics.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Assures Rochambeau that derogatory information which had been given him concerning the strength of the American army is not correct, and that Lafayette's estimate of the troops which can be raised is not exaggerated. He also writes that he believes that Washington would be willing to take advice from Rochambeau.

did.unittitle: Letter (unsigned). 4 pages, folio. With an enclosure, in French, 2 1/2 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A lengthy explanation of the purchases of supplies of flour, horses and wagons, for the use of the French army in America. The accompanying document is a statement of the expenses.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, folio. With an enclosure, in French, 1 page, folio. Philadelphia. The enclosure reads, En Conseil Philadelphie le 25. Juillet 1780. With note in La Luzerne's hand on p. 2.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Requests instructions on dealing with deserters from Hessian regiments. The enclosure is a translation into French of a letter from Joseph Reed, stating that there is no objection to deserters being enlisted in the French army.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 1/2 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News that the horses bought for the French army in Maryland and Pennsylvania are being sent on to Rochambeau; that he has received no news at all of the second division of the French troops; and of a projected attack on Jamaica.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Compliments Rochambeau on the coolness with which he has faced the abortive English attack on Newport.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Informs Rochambeau that he has written to Vergennes that the French assistance must be effective, if given at all. He also explains why the supplies bought for the French army have cost so much. The date has been corrected from "Juillet" at top.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/4 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Urges a reproof of Holker, the French purchasing agent, for the poor use he has made of the money advanced by La Luzerne.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 2 pages, 8vo. With an enclosure, a copy of the letter to Tarle "datée de philadelphie le 23 aout 1780", in French, 7 pages, folio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Admits that the French agents have been outrageously overcharged for supplies. The enclosure is a copy of a seven page letter sent to General Tarle, finance officer of Rochambeau, regarding the purchases made for the French army.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 4 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Approves Rochambeau's decision to ignore letters from Washington's intermediaries, and ascribes Lafayette's indiscretions to his inexperience and his desire to have the French army come into action. He also suggests that he consider the use of his troops against Charleston, S.C. if naval superiority is attained, and explains that the public did not understand the good reasons for the inaction of the army.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages, folio. With enclosure, translation into French of letters of Gates and Sumter, 5 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The enclosure gives the news of the disastrous defeat at Camden. La Luzerne comments that this defeat opens all of the Carolinas to British invasion, which he predicts will soon come. He also speaks of purchases of horses being made near Lancaster, Pa., and of the expected arrival of dispatches from France on the Alliance , which had just arrived at Boston.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 1/2 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News that the German prisoners of war in western Pennsylvania had spread unfavorable rumors concerning the French troops. He proposes that the Counts de Deux Ponts make a tour of those parts spreading counter- propaganda.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Extends an invitation to further visits by French officers to Pennsylvania; and expresses the hope that Rochambeau himself can pay a visit to Congress. He gives news of operations of the British in Chesapeake Bay, and in the Carolinas.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 2 pages, 4to. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerns the dispatches from France, which have not yet arrived. He also reports that the second division has not yet left France, and appears unlikely to do so soon.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages, 4to. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A (false) report of the death of Col. Tarleton is forwarded, with news that a large British force is being sent to the south. Movements of troops and ships in Europe and America are also mentioned.

did.unittitle: Note, in French, in a secretary's hand concerning Rochambeau's correspondence with La Luzerne. 1 page, 4to. No place.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Rochambeau's secretary notes that a letter was sent to La Luzerne on July 12, 1780, just after the former's arrival at Newport, of which no copy was kept.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 2 pages, 4to. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerns financial difficulties in Philadelphia. In response to an appeal from Rochambeau, he says that he is able to furnish only 40 to 60,000 livres, and that money is extremely scarce.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 10 1/2 pages, folio. Partly in code, with accompanying decode on a separate page. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A long description of the revolt of the Pennsylvania troops. He goes on to describe, in the coded portion of the letter, the panic which affected some members of Congress.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Further news of the revolt of the Pennsylvania troops, with a description of their rejection of the offers of an emissary from Clinton.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 3 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Military news from the South; the reinforcement of Cornwallis by General Leslie; the position of Greene's troops; the movements of Benedict Arnold in Virginia. He assures Rochambeau that his answer to Washington regarding a combined operation with some Spanish troops in the South was the right one.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 6 pages, folio. Mostly in code, with accompanying separate decode, 2 1/4 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Deals at length with the financially embarrassed position of the French forces, and also urges that a raid be made by the fleet in Chesapeake Bay.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 3 pages, 8vo. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News of the siege of Gibraltar, of the arrival of Rochambeau's son in France, and of the business negotiations relative to the sale of drafts on France.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 3 pages, folio. Partly in code, with accompanying decode, 1 page, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Writes about the raid carried out in Chesapeake Bay by a battleship and two frigates under the command of Tilly; about the impending campaign of the Spaniards under the command of Galvez against Pensacola; and about Washington's correspondence with Rochambeau regarding a stronger attack against the British in Chesapeake Bay.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 1/2 pages, folio. Mostly in code, with decode on an accompanying sheet, 1 1/4 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Discusses a loan made by Mr. Price which needed to be repaid, and suggests that a fast-sailing frigate be sent to Havana, where funds would be available.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 3 1/2 pages, folio. Almost entirely in code, with accompanying decode, 1 1/4 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Agrees with Rochambeau's plan to send an expedition to Chesapeake Bay, and informs him that Lafayette is already at the head of the Bay, waiting for him there. He also gives news of the march of Lord Cornwallis' army to Virginia.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 1 page, 4to. With translation into French of a letter of Thomas Jefferson, "Copie d'une Lettre de Mr. Jefferson au President du Congres en datte de Richmond le 26. Fevr.," 1 1/2 pages, 4to. [Philadelphia.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Jefferson's letter gives an overview of the state of Cornwallis' army, which leads La Luzerne to predict a "seconde affaire de Saratoga." On the date the word "mai" has been crossed through.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 4 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A long description of the course of the war in the South. Morgan's victory over Tarleton at Cowpens is described, as well as the complicated maneuvers between Greene and Cornwallis, the attacks by the Creek and Cherokee Indians on the frontiers, and the Arnold expedition in Chesapeake Bay.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 3 pages, 8vo. [Philadelphia]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Results of the raid to Chesapeake Bay by Tilly. He repeats his plea for Rochambeau to send a ship to Havana to obtain hard cash.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 4 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Another plea for settlement of the French debts at Philadelphia. He reveals that the failure of reinforcements for the Rhode Island fleet to arrive was caused by the fact that Admiral de Guichen did not give the code book to Admiral de Monteil, who was therefore unable to read his letters. Lafayette has sailed down Chesapeake Bay, and is waiting at Annapolis to go farther.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 1/4 pages, folio. Partly in code, with interlinear decode. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: More about the missing ships. He urges Rochambeau to send news of the true state of affairs to France immediately, so that there will be no mistaken assumptions when plans were made. He repeats the story of his previous letter about the missing code book.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 7 pages, folio. Partly in code, with interlinear decode, and an accompanying paper, "Subsistance de L'armee" dated Philadelphie le 26. mars 1781, 2 1/2 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The enclosure is a copy of his communication to a committee of Congress which dealt with the Franklin- Necker contract. In the letter, in a coded portion, he states that he has written to the French government about the precarious financial situation. He also recommends that subsidy funds sent from France be kept strictly secret, as they would otherwise be wasted or cause a slackening of efforts by Congress.
