did.unittitle: Letter signed. 3 1/2 pages, folio. Partly in code, with interlinear decode. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Expresses his regret that the Chesapeake expedition under Destouches has been so unfruitful, and calls for action in the South. He thanks Rochambeau for the settlement of the Price loan in specie, and condemns the conduct of Holker.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 2 pages, 4to. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tells Rochambeau that the battle of Cape Henry has greatly changed the opinion of Americans about the French navy. He informs Rochambeau that a great naval force was being prepared in France, probably for America, and that it was of the greatest importance that both Rochambeau and the American army be ready to act when assistance comes.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 4 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: More about the financing of the French army. He again objects to the financial dealings of Holker.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 4 pages, folio. Partly in code, with interlinear decode. With an enclosure, "Lettre du Général Washington à Mr. Lund Washington en Virginie interceptée par les anglois et publiée dans le papier de New-York," 2 1/2 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sends Rochambeau a translation into French of the intercepted letter from George Washington to Lund Washington, and tells him that he saw no harm in the criticism. He also writes about relieving the Southern States, about the intention of the French ministry to send further help to America, and again about the necessity of keeping secret any funds sent to America as a subsidy. He also mentions the Franklin-Necker contract.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages, 4to. With an enclosure, "By the united States in Congress assembled. April 11th. 1781. Resolved... Charles Thomson Secreta.," 1 page, 4to. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: He forwards to Rochambeau a copy of a Resolution of Congress stating that they will "take every measure in their power for furnishing the supplies to the amount of four hundred thousand Dollars...."

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages, folio. Partly in code, with interlinear decode. With an enclosure, in French, 2 pages 4to. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sends extracts from letters of Vergennes and Castries regarding the failure of Admiral de Monteil to send five additional ships to Rhode Island.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 2 1/4 pages, 4to. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The latest news from the South.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 1 page, 4to. With an enclosure, "Lettre de Mr. Le Ch. De La Luzerne a Mr. Destouches du 7. may 1781," 3 1/4 pages, folio. Partly in code, with interlinear decode. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A plea for an expedition to Chesapeake Bay. The enclosure is a decipher of a letter to Destouches about the situation in the Southern States, and suggesting that if the French ships could change their base to the Bay, that the pressure against these States would be relieved.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerns the crash of the Continental currency. A sentence which has been heavily marked over relates to the Washington letter criticizing the French Admirals.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News of the fleet from France, and of the state of affairs in Virginia.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 1/2 pages, folio. With an enclosure, in French, "Memoire," signed. 7 1/2 pages, folio. Blank corner torn from last page. philadelphie le 20 avril [i.e. may?] 1781. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Urges speed in starting the coming campaign. Enclosure contains his ideas for the coming campaign. It is certain that the April date is a clerical error, as on the next to last page he refers to the impending conference between Rochambeau and Washington, which took place on May 23rd. He urges that all naval and land forces available be sent to Chesapeake Bay.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 3 pages, folio. Partly in code, with interlinear decode. With an enclosed copy of a letter to Washington, Philae. le 1er. Juin 1781. 2 1/2 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: He repeats his fears that the southern states will be forced to make peace with the British. In the enclosed letter, a reply to Washington's letter of May 23rd, he also informs Washington that the French government is granting a subsidy of 6,000,000 livres.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Expresses his dissatisfaction with the results of the Wethersfield Conference.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 1 page, 4to. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News of the arrival of a British convoy and of a small reinforcement for the garrisons of Charleston, St. Augustine, etc.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 3 1/2 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Regards Robert Morris' proposal for the furnishing of supplies to the French army. He praises Morris' measures for the establishment of American credit.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 1 page, 4to. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reports has heard no news whatever concerning the fleet of Admiral de Grasse.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. One sentence in code, with interlinear decode. 1 page, 4to. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News of Cornwallis' retreat to Yorktown.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages, 4to. Mostly in code, with interlinear decode. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News that de Grasse is expected momentarily at Cap Français, St. Domingue.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, 4to. With 3 enclosures, all in French: "Copie d'une Lettre de Mr. le Comte de Grasse à M. le Chevalier de la Luzerne, du Cap le 28. Juillet 1781." 2 pages, folio, mostly in code with interlinear decode; "Copie d'une Lettre trouvée à Bord d'un paque bot D'Antigue qui a été pris et conduit dans le Port de Philadelphie...Signé Richd. Nash. - Antigue le 6. Aout 1781." 1 1/2 pages 4to.; "A Philadelphie le 21 aout 1781." 1 1/2 pages, 4to. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The latest news from de Grasse. He encloses a copy of the Admiral's letter to him which is substantially the same as de Grasse's letter to Rochambeau. The other two enclosures relate to news of the return of Admiral Hood's fleet to England.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 1 page, 4to. [Philadelphia]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous news of naval affairs in Europe.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages (including postscript), folio. With an enclosure, "Nouvelles de Newyorck. 7bre. 1781," 1 page, 4to. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Information on changes in the British naval command. In a postscript, and on the enclosed paper, he tells of reported ship movements in New York, which were apparently sending troops to Virginia.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 4 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News of the naval battle off Chesapeake Bay between the fleets of de Grasse and Graves. He also writes about the supply of flour for the army, the possibility of an attack on Philadelphia, and money for the army.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerns the arrival of funds for the French army.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, 4to. With an autograph notation by Rochambeau. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Suggests that a chain of dispatch riders be established between the French and American headquarters. Rochambeau's note states that the letter was received Dec. 15.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 3 pages, 4to. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Warns that money he is expecting from France may not arrive as soon as he expects; also mentions ship movements, the exchange of prisoners, etc.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 2 1/2 pages, 4to. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News that Lafayette, leaving for France, will carry Rochambeau's dispatches to the French government. He complains of the slow mail service, and says that any news reaching Philadelphia will be sent on immediately.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 1/4 pages, 4to. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Because of the failure of funds to arrive from France, he recommends raising money in Philadelphia by drafts on France, which he says are nearly at par.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages 4to. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News of the capture of a French vessel bound for Havana.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages, 4to. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Requests that if money is needed later, it not be raised by paying the contractors for supplies in paper, but by dealing with financiers in Philadelphia, as there is less loss that way.

did.unittitle: Menonville, François-Louis-Thibaut de.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Unless otherwise indicated, all letters from Menonville to Rochambeau are in French.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 1 page, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A report on his mission to obtain supplies, and his difficulties because of the total collapse of the Continental paper currency.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 3 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A further report on the difficulties caused in financing the French army in America, because of the fall of Continental paper money. He suggests some cost-saving measures.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed, from Vioménil, Antoine Charles du Houx, Baron de to Menonville, in French. 4 pages, 4to. Newport.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A reply on behalf of Rochambeau, to Menonville's two letters. He expresses complete approval of the course Menonville has taken in not contracting for supplies in Philadelphia, and tells him that Rochambeau is contracting in New England for what the army needed.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 3 1/2 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerning the financial and supply situation, with some military news. After a long discussion of the purchases of supplies made by the French agents, he reports on a discussion with Robert Morris. He also gives the latest news of operations by Generals Greene, Cornwallis, and Lafayette.

did.unittitle: FRENCH NAVY IN AMERICA
Washington to Admiral Ternay
Copy of a letter ("au quartier général de Bergen County Le 16. 7bre. 1780") and annexed intelligence report ("du 14. 7bre.") to Admiral Ternay, translated into French. 1 1/2 pages, 4to.
Grandchain de Semonville, Guillaume J. C. L. de
Autograph letter signed, to La Pérouse, in French. 3 pages, 4to. Newport.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The latest news from the French headquarters in Newport regarding orders from Destouches, then in command of the Newport fleet. He also writes of an exchange of prisoners, and of financial matters.

did.unittitle: Grasse, François Joseph Paul de Grasse, comte de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Unless otherwise indicated, all letters from de Grasse to Rochambeau are in French.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages, folio. "A Bord de la ville de paris en mer." With an autograph note by Rochambeau on the first page. With enclosed list of de Grasse's fleet. 2 pages, folio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A report that the French fleet is under way, and that it will be ready to participate in an offensive against the English armies during the summer. With an accompanying list of the naval forces under his command. Rochambeau's note on the first page states that he received it on the 10th of June when his army was just setting out from Providence.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages, folio. With an autograph postscript by de Grasse. Cap-François, St. Domingue.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerns the beginning of the Yorktown campaign. He states he will leave with 25 to 29 warships on August 3 to Chesapeake Bay, and that he can remain no longer than the 15th of October. The postscript, in the handwriting of de Grasse, relates to the furnishing of pilots for Chesapeake Bay. This letter is listed and reproduced in The American Campaigns of Rochambeau's Army 1780, 1781, 1782, 1783 , trans. and ed. by Howard C. Rice, Jr., and Anne S. K. Brown, Vol. I, pp. xvii-xviii and between pp. 60 and 61. It was exhibited at the National Museum of American History, Smithsonian Institution, in the 1981 exhibition, "By Sea and Land: Independence with the Help of France."

did.unittitle: Retained copy of a letter, from Washington and Rochambeau to de Grasse. 6 1/2 pages, folio. "Camp at Phillipsburg." With an autograph translation into French by Rochambeau, 1 1/2 pages, folio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The decision to engage the British in Virginia rather than attack New York. They go on to present three possible scenarios after the French fleet's arrival in the Chesapeake and suggested action regarding each. This is Rochambeau's file copy.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 1/2 pages, 4to. "dans la baye de Chesapeack, A Bord De La Ville de Paris."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Announcement of his arrival. He also discusses the events of his voyage, and other military details, ending with his pledge to do all he can to establish American independence.

did.unittitle: Letter to La Luzerne (copy). 3/4 page, 4to. Directly below is a letter to La Luzerne from Lafayette (copy). 2 1/4 pages, 4to. "Dattée de la Baye de Chesapeack le 30 aout 1781." [and] "de holts forge le 1 7bre." [1781], respectively.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: De Grasse announces his arrival in American waters. Lafayette gives a detailed account of the positions of his forces and the enemy, and of the plans he has for containing Cornwallis until the French-American army arrives.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, folio. "au Cap henry."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Written in reply to a joint letter from Rochambeau and Washington. He writes that he has only warships with him, and gives details of the operations against Cornwallis conducted by Lafayette and Saint-Simon.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, 4to. "au Cap henry."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A report on the readiness of ships to transport troops.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 3 pages, folio. With autograph postscript by de Grasse. "a bord de la ville de Paris."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: States he will keep his fleet at the same mooring in order to prevent a British force from entering Chesapeake Bay. He requests water, firewood, and fresh supplies for his sick.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, 4to. "Ville De paris a 1 heur apres mid."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A sudden change of plans, that, as soon as the winds will permit, he will sail from the Bay, and gives instructions as to how to return the infantry and artillery troops to the West Indies.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 3 pages, 4to. [Chesapeake Bay; there is a pencil notation on the first page of the letter, "c. Aug. 30 - Sept. 4, 1781."] 1781 [Sep 25]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerns the arrangements for the accommodation of the French fleet. The first two lines of the letter are in the handwriting of Lafayette.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 2 1/4 pages, 4to. [Chesapeake Bay.] Addressed on p. 4

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Agrees to supply 800 more men from the fleet to take part in the operations against Yorktown. He notes that he has a large number of sick and wounded and will be shorthanded after sending the 800 men.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 1 page, 4to. [Chesapeake Bay; there is a pencil notation at the bottom of the first page of the letter, "(ca. Oct. 1, 1781).] Addressed on p. 4.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A demand that the French navy be kept informed of the progress of the siege of Yorktown, by receiving a daily bulletin.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, folio. [Chesapeake Bay], le 5 8bre. 1781. With an enclosed report, "Rapport fait par le commandant d'un Bateau arrêté en sortant de la Riviere D'york, par les chalouppe des Vaisseaux qui en ferment le Blocus." 2 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerns the progress of the Yorktown siege. He warns that his ships can accomplish nothing because of the lack of pilots; speaks of his lack of bread on the ships, and other matters. The report of the ship's officer, who had been captured attempting to escape from Yorktown in a small vessel, gives a picture of events within the besieged town.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 1 page, 4to. [Chesapeake Bay], "a 8 heur sur Matin." Addressed on p. 4.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerns the bombardment of Yorktown by the French and American forces, which he had heard from the Bay.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 2 pages, 4to. [Chesapeake Bay].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Complains of the lack of flour in the fleet, and the methods for getting a supply to him.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 2 1/2 pages, 4to. [Chesapeake Bay].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Expresses concern over the possibility that the English fleet might enter Chesapeake Bay, and that he would be unable to drive them off. He also complains about the lack of fresh meat, water, and firewood. He then discusses the possibility of Cornwallis abandoning his artillery and heavy baggage and attempting to escape.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 1 page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Forwards a Hessian officer's request for news of his friends in Yorktown. A list of the officers accompanies the letter. He also refers to ship movements in connection with the siege.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, 4to. With an autograph postscript, 1 page. [Chesapeake Bay].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In the first portion of the letter, he tells Rochambeau that he has written to Washington about the blockading of the York River. See The Writings of George Washington , ed. John C. Fitzpatrick, vol. 23, pp. 208-209, 225-226. In the postscript he complains again about the shortage of food supplies.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages, folio. "A bord de la Ville de Paris."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: He apologizes for an ill-tempered letter he had sent, then gives details about the delivery of gunpowder to Washington. He also expresses his hopes that the siege of Yorktown will end as soon as possible.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, 4to. With an autograph postscript. [Chesapeake Bay].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A request that Rochambeau forward to La Luzerne the enemy signal books. He also bids farewell to Rochambeau.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, 4to. [Chesapeake Bay.] Addressed on p. 4.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Arrangements are concluded for the hospitalization of the sick and wounded of the French fleet at Williamsburg. Reports on the captured English ships that are being left at Yorktown, and requests that the captured English sailors be sent to Europe rather than exchanged, to deprive them of crews for their ships.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 3 pages, 4to. [Chesapeake Bay].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Further discussion of transport for the troops in Virginia. He informs Rochambeau that he will keep the fleet only a few days longer in Chesapeake Bay, and will then have to depart.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 3 pages, 4to. [Chesapeake Bay], "a 2 au soir." 1781 Oct

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A discussion of the cooperation between the land and sea forces in the siege of Yorktown. He mentions the difficulties with Washington's correspondence, asking Rochambeau to translate the letters before sending them on.

did.unittitle: Destouches, Charles René Dominique Sochet

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Unless otherwise indicated, all letters from Destouches to Rochambeau are in French.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 1 page, 4to. [Newport].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A comment on a letter Rochambeau had sent him with news from Europe. He says that if the French forces in America were not reinforced, there was no hope for a successful campaign.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 1 page, 4to. [Newport]. Addressed on p. 4.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: States that a force of 75 soldiers will be sufficient to serve on a frigate and a cutter.

did.unittitle: "Copy of a Letter from General Washington to the Count de Rochambeau. Dated from head quarters, New Windsor, April 10th. 1781." 3 pages, folio. With certification at the end signed by Destouches. With autograph translation in the handwriting of Rochambeau. 2 pages, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A discussion of a proposed raid on British forces in the Penobscot region by a French naval detachment under his command. Washington approves the plan, but points out the difficulties of operations in the region. Rochambeau had sent the original of the letter to Destouches, who returned this copy "Collationne conformement a l'original" to him.

did.unittitle: Barras, Jacques Melchior, comte de Saint Laurent

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Unless otherwise indicated, all letters from Barras to Rochambeau are in French.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages, 4to. a Newport. With a postscript dated "Le 2 Juillet au Matin." Half page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reports of ship movements of the small fleet in Newport He tells him of the arrival of a French convoy from Boston, and discusses British army reinforcements sent to Charleston against General Greene.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages, folio. Partly in code, with interlinear decode. Newport.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Requests that Rochambeau inform him of the plans that are being made for cooperation with the fleet of Admiral de Grasse. He describes the mishaps of an expedition made against a force of Loyalists who were supposed to be on Block Island.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 4 pages, folio. About half in code, with interlinear decode. Newport.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A discussion of the plans for a possible attack on New York after the arrival of de Grasse. He expresses resistance to a suggestion from Washington that he join the fleet of when it arrives.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 3 1/2 pages, folio. About half in code, with interlinear decode. Newport.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: He continues to argue against the desirability of leaving Newport to join de Grasse, alleging that he would run the risk of being driven back into the port, and forced to burn his ships.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, 4to. Partly in code, (not decoded). Newport.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A note at the beginning of this letter reads "Chiffre de M. de Vergennes." This was not the proper code, as it is not decoded here, and the whole letter is repeated, with the coded portions in the proper code, below. He requests the return of some sailors who had deserted to Rochambeau's army.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, 4to. Newport.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A short letter concerning dispatches to Europe.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 1/2 pages, 4to. Partly in cipher, with interlinear decipher. Newport.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Repeats the entire letter of the 3rd of August, with the coded portions in the proper code. He adds further news concerning a convoy which had left New York for Quebec, and concerning the fleet of de Grasse.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 1/4 pages, folio. Almost entirely in code, with interlinear decode. Newport "à 6 heures du soir."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News of the impending arrival of Admiral de Grasse. Barras gives a transcript of de Grasse's letter to him, which is, in substance, the same as the letter of July 28th to Rochambeau.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages, folio. Partly in code, with interlinear decode. Newport.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Proposes a raid on Newfoundland. He also writes of the dangers of trying to bring the French fleet into New York harbor.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 3 pages, folio. Partly in code, with interlinear decode. Newport.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: He abandons his plan for a trip to Newfoundland. He decides to go to Chesapeake with his squadron, and to convoy artillery there.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, 4to. Newport. With an enclosure, dated "Du 17. Aout 1781." 1 page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A report of the arrival of a frigate in Boston bringing 1,800,000 livres for the expenses of the army, and of other ship movements. The enclosure is an intelligence report from a Capt. Henry Weeden concerning Halifax (ships stationed there, fortifications, etc.).

did.unittitle: Duportail, Louis le Beque
Autograph letter signed. 1 page, 4to. "Cape henry a bord de la ville de paris." Addressed on p. 4.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An appeal to hasten the march to Virginia. See The Writings of George Washington , ed. John C. Fitzpatrick, vol. 23, p. 10.

did.unittitle: La Pérouse, Jean-François de Galaup, comte de
Autograph letter signed. 3 pages, 4to. "A bord de L'Astrée."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: La Pérouse writes that he will not send back La Resolue , but another ship instead.

did.unittitle: Langle, Paul Antoine Marie Fleuriot, vicomte de
Autograph letter signed. 2 1/2 pages, 4to. "a bord de la resolue a nantasquet."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: States that his orders are conflicting, and that he is going to sail with La Pérouse for the West Indies but can return from thence to Chesapeake Bay.

did.unittitle: FRENCH ARMY UNDER ROCHAMBEAU

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Unless otherwise indicated, all letters from Choisy to Rochambeau are in French.

did.unittitle: Choisy, Claude Gabriel, marquis de
Autograph letter signed. 4 pages, 4to. Newport.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The poor results of the raids on Loyalist detachments at Block Island and Huntington, Long Island. He complains of the failure of the promised militia troops to appear in sufficient numbers and speaks of the heavy artillery which was being sent to Providence for safety.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 4 pages, 4to. Newport.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News that Barras is determined not to leave Newport before some news arrives from de Grasse, and requests that Barras be kept informed of Washington's plans for the campaign. He gives further details of the Block Island and Huntington raids.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 3 pages, 4to. Newport.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Thanks Rochambeau for sending him the journal of the proceedings of his army after reaching Phillipsburg. He again speaks of Barras' unwillingness to leave Newport before the arrival of de Grasse.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed, to Rochambeau, in French. 2 pages, 4to. Newport.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Asks permission to furnish gunpowder for a Boston privateer. He also requests orders regarding a number of French officers on parole in New York. He also explains that the fortifications planned for Newport were progressing at a very slow rate.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 1 page, 4to. "a bord de la ville de paris."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News of the 800 men supplied by de Grasse from the fleet to take part in the siege of Yorktown.

did.unittitle: THE FRENCH COURT

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: All letters are in French.

did.unittitle: Necker, Jacques
Autograph letter signed. 4 pages, 4to. With an autograph note by Rochambeau on the first page. [Paris?]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Informs Rochambeau that currency and letters of credit are being sent to him. Rochambeau notes that the letter was received on Jan. 28, 1781.

did.unittitle: Ségur, Philippe-Henri, marquis de
Letter signed. 4 pages, folio. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Answers to a series of requests from Rochambeau, regarding pay of various troops and workmen attached to the French army in America, the sending of additional specialist troops (for artillery), etc.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 3 1/2 pages, folio. About half in code, with interlinear decode. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Approval of Rochambeau's conduct at the Hartford conference, with the assurance that a plentiful supply of money, both in specie and in notes, was being sent on to him.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. All in code, except subscription, with interlinear decode. Versailles. With note on p. 4.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An order to furnish men and supplies to Capt. La Pérouse for his Hudson's Bay raid.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, folio. With an autograph docket by Rochambeau. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A request from Queen Marie Antoinette that Rochambeau give M. de Lameth, an officer in his army, any services he possibly can.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, folio. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A request from King Louis XVI that the comte de Fersen be given the opportunity to give proof of his loyalty.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 3 1/4 pages, folio. With duplicate copy of letter with notation on the last page that it was received Dec. 15 at Williamsburg. All in code, except subscription, with interlinear decode. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Information to Rochambeau concerning the vessels in which the money promised is being shipped.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. Half page, folio. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter which accompanied a list of promotions of various officers in Rochambeau's army. (List not present).

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/4 pages, folio. All in code, except subscription, with interlinear decode. With autograph note by Rochambeau. Marly.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: He orders Rochambeau to make a strict inquiry into the reasons for the unfavorable rate of exchange, and to report back. Rochambeau's note states the late arrival of this and other letters.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, folio. Marly.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A complaint that he has received no news from Rochambeau, though the former has heard of the safe arrival of L'Astrée (under La Pérouse) in America.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/4 pages, folio. Marly.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Notification that supplies are being sent for the use of the American army. He reminds Rochambeau that the King wishes to have the French army supply the needs of the Americans so far as they can.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, folio. With a duplicate copy. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An acknowledgement of Rochambeau's dispatch dated March 16, giving an account of the sea battle of Cape Henry. He also mentions Rochambeau's letter to Washington of March 31st, in which a junction of the two armies was proposed.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages, folio. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Informs Rochambeau that the King is highly pleased with his good relations with Washington. He requests, however, that Washington's replies to Rochambeau's letters be sent in full, instead of in abridged versions.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/4 pages, folio. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Expresses his satisfaction that Washington's intercepted letter had caused no bad feeling between the French and the Americans.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, folio. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An approval of the support which Rochambeau had given to La Pérouse in fitting out his ships for the Hudson's Bay raid.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, folio. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The King's approval of the decision of the May 31 Council of War at Newport.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, folio. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Approval of the decision of the June 8 Council of War at Newport.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 3 1/2 pages (including postscript), folio. With another postscript, 2 1/2 pages, folio. About half of the letter, and all of the additional postscript, in code, with interlinear decode. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Approval of the measures taken for the defense of Newport. The enclosed postscript states that Rochambeau's dispatches are personally examined by the King, and that the King had found them difficult to read because of Rochambeau's practice of putting short passages in code throughout the letter.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, 4to. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Permission for the Chevalier de Chastellux to return to France if necessary, for reasons of health.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, 4to. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In response to a request from Rochambeau that he be permitted to return to France because of poor health, he is told that it is of the greatest importance that he should finish the year's campaign.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, folio. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gives the names of several officers serving in America who are to awarded the Croix de St. Louis.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 6 pages, folio, sewn. Entirely in code, except for last paragraph, with interlinear decode. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Informs him that his request for relief because of ill health is granted; and requests that he send word of the date it is to take effect. A letter transferring the command to the Baron de Vioménil is included. (This letter is not present.)

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 3 1/2 pages, folio. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reply to a complaint of Rochambeau that his army was being overloaded with medical corpsmen.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, folio. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reply to a dispatch containing a journal of army operations after its junction with Washington's army, and the manuscript of the Dobbs Ferry conference with Washington. Ségur states that the King has approved all that he has done, and is highly pleased that Rochambeau and Washington are in agreement.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 5 1/2 pages, folio, sewn. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An explanation for the adoption of a policy of selling goods to the American army for the benefit of the French army.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 4 pages, folio. About 2/3 in code, with interlinear decode. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Acknowledges receipt of dispatches covering the beginnings of the Yorktown campaign, and approves the actions he has taken. He urges Rochambeau to formulate plans for the coming winter so that some idea could be had of the supplies and money necessary for the support of the army.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, folio. With autograph docket by Rochambeau. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Instructions of the King for the singing of a Te Deum in honor of the birth of a son.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 1/2 pages, folio. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Praise for Rochambeau's handling of his army in America and the friendship he has maintained with Washington.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, folio. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Transmitting a letter of Louis XVI ordering a Te Deum for the victory of Yorktown.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/4 pages, folio. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Further commendations from the King on the unexpectedly large number of prisoners, and on the small number of casualties in the French army. He informs Rochambeau that the list of officers recommended for decorations is being scrutinized.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 3 pages, folio. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Rochambeau is reproved for having given a commission in a regiment to a relative, M. de L'Auberdiere, without regard to the seniority of the other officers of the regiment.

did.unittitle: Letter signed, to the comte de L'Auberdiere. 1 page, folio. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter giving L'Auberdiere promotion to the rank of Captain of Cavalry or Dragoons when a vacancy at that rank occurs.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages, folio. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Following a long laudatory paragraph summarizing Rochambeau's services in America, he is promised the command of the first military district command to fall vacant with a pay of 30,000 livres, the pay to begin immediately. His son is promised command of a regiment in advance of his seniority.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, folio. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Orders the Croix de St. Louis to be given to Lieut. Gen. Tarle for his services, and ordering him to pay a reward to Tarle's subordinates for their services.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, folio. With an enclosure, 1 page, folio. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Orders for promotions, decorations, and payments of various sums of money to officers of engineers who had distinguished themselves at Yorktown.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, folio. With enclosure, 1 page, folio. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The officers of the artillery corps who distinguished themselves at Yorktown are here rewarded with promotions, decorations and various money rewards.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, folio. With enclosure, "Copie de la Lettre Ecrite le 5. Décembre 1781 a M. le Mis. de la fayette par le Mis. de Segur," 2 pages, folio. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Informs Rochambeau of the promotion of Lafayette to the rank of "Marechal de Camp" in the French army.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 6 pages, folio, sewn. Entirely in code, except for subscription, with interlinear decode. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Permission to turn over the command to Baron de Vioménil whenever necessary.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, folio. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Rochambeau's commission as commander-in-chief of the province of Picardy.

did.unittitle: Letter signed, to Rochambeau, in French. 1 page, folio. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Assignment of the sum of 36,000 livres as his annual pay as commander of Picardy.

did.unittitle: Castries, marquis de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Full heading: Castries, Charles Eugène Gabriel de la Croix, marquis de.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 2 pages, folio. With autograph notation by Rochambeau. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Informs Rochambeau that de Grasse has been ordered to cooperate with him in operations in North America. Rochambeau notes that he received this letter from de Grasse in Chesapeake Bay on Sept. 17th, 1781.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, folio. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Informs Rochambeau of the appointment of de Barras as the successor of the late Admiral Ternay in command of the French fleet at Newport.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, folio. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An expedition is ordered, under the command of La Pérouse, to go to Hudson's Bay to attack the English posts there. Rochambeau is directed to supply him with soldiers for the expedition, and to otherwise assist him.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter signed. 2 pages, 4to. Brest.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A notification that de Grasse is on his way to America, with 20 ships. He also tells him that 1,500,000 livres is being shipped to him in several ships.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, folio. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Acknowledgement of Rochambeau's letter in which he had informed him of the measures he was taking to assist La Pérouse in his Hudson's Bay raid.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 page, folio. Versailles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An acknowledgement of Rochambeau's letter in which he had informed him of the Council of War held at Newport, June 8th, 1781. Castries also refers to the harmonious relations between Rochambeau and Washington.

did.unittitle: Joly de Fleury, Jean François
Letter signed. 1 1/3 pages, folio. Paris.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A notification that the sum of 2,500,000 francs in specie was being sent to the American forces.

did.unittitle: Letter signed. 1 1/2 pages, 4to. Paris.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An acknowledgement of the receipt of Rochambeau's letter of July 8th.

did.unittitle: Conference Papers and Other Documents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II, Conference Papers and Other Documents , is organized into two subseries: Conferences Papers and Other Documents.

did.unittitle: CONFERENCE PAPERS
Wethersfield Conference (May 13-23, 1781)
Drafts in the hands of Rochambeau and Barras of the Wethersfield Propositions. Newport.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph manuscript signed, and manuscript signed, 4 pages, folio, double column; consisting of the first draft of the Wethersfield "Propositions" nos. 1 and 2 in the right hand column of pages 1-3 in the hand of a secretary, signed by Rochambeau; Barras' replies, in his autograph, signed at end, in the left hand columns, pages 1-2; and rough drafts, heavily corrected, in the handwriting of Rochambeau, of Propositions 3-5, on pages 3-4.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Preliminary drafts of the propositions put before Washington at Wethersfield. The first two, calling for replies by Admiral Barras, were communicated to him in this manuscript. Barras wrote out his replies, and returned the manuscript to Rochambeau, who then added, in his handwriting, drafts of the last three propositions. These various writings were combined, the Barras answers being incorporated in the text of the Propositions, to form the manuscript which was submitted to Washington.

did.unittitle: Propositions by Rochambeau and Barras and replies of Washington. Newport.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manuscript, partly autograph, signed, in double column; consisting of 8 pages, folio, with the "Propositions" in French, in the right hand columns; in the left hand columns are the replies of Washington translated into French; all the above being in the hand of a secretary, except the postscriptum of one page, in the autograph of Rochambeau, a signed comment of Barras at the end of Proposition 2, and a short note by Barras at the end of the 5th Proposition; signatures of Rochambeau and Barras at the end of the 5th Proposition. Also: Barras, Comte de. Letter signed, to Rochambeau. 1 page, 4to. Newport. 17 Mai 1781.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The first note by Barras, at the end of Proposition 2, states that the above are his replies to the questions of Rochambeau. The second note of Barras states his agreement with Rochambeau on the last three propositions. The Barras letter is a request for 700 men to replace casualties from battle and sickness. In the autograph manuscript postscriptum, Rochambeau details the events of the 17th and 18th of May.

did.unittitle: Wethersfield propositions made by Rochambeau and Washington's answers. Wethersfield.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph manuscript signed, and manuscript signed, double column; consisting of a series of 5 propositions and a postscript, signed by Rochambeau, on the left hand of each page, and autograph manuscript, "Observations by Genl. Washington," in the right hand column of each page, signed at the end. 11 pages, folio. Wethersfield.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Washington here gives his answers to Barras' questions. Rochambeau's Propositions are given in only a brief form in The Writings of George Washington , ed. John C. Fitzpatrick, vol. 22, pp. 105-106. The first four Propositions have to do with planning for the defense of Newport and Providence. The junction of the Armies is the subject of the 5th Proposition, and a preference is indicated for an attack on New York rather than the South. Added to the above is a manuscript, in the hand of a secretary, giving an account of the strength of the American army, and an estimate of the strength of the British in New York. The manuscript is 1 1/2 pages, folio, and undated, but apparently of the period of this conference.

did.unittitle: Newport Conference (May 31 and June 8, 1781)
Grandchain de Semonville, Guillaume J.C.L. de
Manuscript, in French, "Séance du Conseil assemblé à bord du Vaisseau du Roi le Duc de Bourgogne," signed. 2 pages, folio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A series of three propositions regarding the posting of the Newport fleet after the departure of Rochambeau and his army to the South.

did.unittitle: Manuscript, in French, "Séance du Conseil tenu à Bord du Vaisseau du Roy Le Neptune," signed. 3 pages, folio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An official copy, signed by Grandchain as Major de l'Escadre.

did.unittitle: Dobbs Ferry Conference (July 1781)
Washington and Rochambeau

Manuscript in the handwriting of Jonathan Trumbull, Jr., signed by Washington alone. In two columns, the Rochambeau text being in the left hand column of each page, the Washington text in the right hand columns. 3 pages, folio. "Camp at Dobbs' ferr[y]."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Resolution of the question of where to attack the British. Only Washington's text is printed in The Writings of George Washington , ed. John C. Fitzpatrick, vol. 22, pp. 395-396.

did.unittitle: Manuscript, in French, in the hand- writing of Rochambeau, "questions du cte. de rochambeau au gal. washington le 18 juillet 1781." (left hand column), and "reponse du gal. washington du 19 juillet 1781" (right column). 1 1/4 pages, folio, double column.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Translation into French of the Dobbs Ferry conference manuscript.

did.unittitle: Philadelphia Conference (July 1782)

Washington, George, and Jean-Baptiste- Donatien de Vimeur, comte de Rochambeau. Autograph manuscript, signed at the end by Washington, in two columns and full page; on pages 1 and 2 (not numbered), double columns with the left hand columns (in English) in the handwriting of Washington, and the right hand columns (in French) in the handwriting of Rochambeau; page 3 (in English; not numbered; full page) entirely in the handwriting of Washington, as also page 4 (in English; not numbered; quarter page only); in all, 3 1/4 pages, folio. Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Plans for a renewal of the fighting, should the diplomatic measures fail. Washington suggests attacking New York or Canada. Rochambeau states that the armies should take a position near New York, so that reinforcements could not be sent to the West Indies by that garrison.

did.unittitle: Washington, George. "Traduction de La reponse de S.E. le general Washington. a Philadelphie." Manuscript, in French, in the hand of a secretary. 3 pages, folio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A translation of Washington's statement at the Conference of Philadelphia.

did.unittitle: OTHER DOCUMENTS
Rochambeau, comte de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Full heading: Rochambeau, Jean-Baptiste-Donatien de Vimeur, comte de. Unless otherwise indicated, all letters by Rochambeau are in French.

did.unittitle: "Campagne - 1781. Journal de ce qui C'est passé depuis l'arrivée du Corps français, au Camp de Phillippsburgh." Manuscript, 12 1/2 pages, folio, sewn. In the hand of a secretary, with two corrections in the hand of Rochambeau on page 1. With 5 blank sheets.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A later corrected draft containing a narrative of events in the French army from July 15-August 15, 1781, as well as a copy of the "Journal des Operations." It was on the 21st-23rd July that the French-American forces undertook operations against Kingsbridge, Morrisania and Throg's Neck. Recorded also are forays into the "no man's land" of Westchester (New Rochelle, Rye, Mamaroneck, Williamsbridge), a bombardment of Tarrytown, etc.

did.unittitle: "Memoire pour regler les mouvements de l'armée alliée dans la nuit du 21 Juillet 1781." Manuscript, in the hand of a secretary, with 3 corrections in the handwriting of Rochambeau. 3 pages, 4to. [Phillipsburg].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Orders outlining the complicated troop movements of the French and American armies in an attack on the New York outposts.

did.unittitle: "ordre du 21 juillet 1781". Autograph manuscript. 1 page, 4to. [Phillipsburg.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Orders to the French troops in an allied attack on the Bronx.

did.unittitle: "Journal des operations du corps Francais, Depuis le 15 Aout." Manuscript, in the hand of a secretary, with corrections in the handwriting of Rochambeau on pages 4 and 12. 14 pages, 4to., sewn. [Phillipsburg to Yorktown]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Narrative of the march of the French army to Virginia, the siege of Yorktown, and the surrender of Cornwallis. From the appearance of the handwriting throughout this volume, it would seem that it is the original day-to-day record dictated by Rochambeau.

did.unittitle: Manuscript, partly autograph, with heading on first page, "1782," and heading on page 16, "1783," giving Rochambeau's narrative of the military and other events of that year and early 1783. 19 1/2 pages, folio, written in half page columns in the hand-writing of a secretary; with additions and corrections in the handwriting of Rochambeau.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Narrative of the military and other events of 1782 and early 1783. The final military movements of the French army; their embarkation and departure from America; the arrest of Rochambeau for an army debt; his return to France and interview with the King; the foundation of the Society of the Cincinnati.

did.unittitle: Continental Congress
Manuscript, in French, containing copies of two Congressional resolutions, and also a resolution of the General Assembly of the State of Pennsylvania. 4 pages, folio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The first Congressional resolution requests the States to pass laws for the arrest of deserters from the French army; the second requests the Governors of Virginia and Maryland to establish a lookout and a chain of posts so that news of the arrival of the French fleet could be brought to Congress as quickly as possible. Dated May 27, June 5, and June 1, 1780, respectively.

did.unittitle: Ciphers and Codes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Five manuscripts, as described below. 14 1/4 pages in all, folio, ca. 1780-1783.

did.unittitle: "Chiffre de Robrt. Morris. Ecuyer. No. 1. with gal greene and robt Morris Esqr." 4 pages, folio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Code with syllables and words represented by numbers. Ciphering copy.

did.unittitle: "Dechiffrement, No. 2. with general greene and robt morris Esq." 3 1/4 pages, folio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Deciphering copy of the above. This and the above were given to Rochambeau by Washington in October, 1781, for the purpose of secret communication between Rochambeau and Greene. The Morris code was supplied, as Greene already had a copy of it.

did.unittitle: Code with words, proper names and place names represented by numbers, in one alphabetical and numerical order; also, a simple substitution cipher. 4 pages, folio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The code and cipher used for secret communication between Washington and Rochambeau.

did.unittitle: "Explanation of the Alphabet." Docketed "chiffre du major talmadge." 1 page, folio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Simple substitution cipher, with a lengthy explanation, intended for secret communication between Tallmadge and Rochambeau. The cipher is exactly the same as in the Washington-Rochambeau code described above.

did.unittitle: "Tableau Pour Chiffrer. Tableau pour Dechiffrer." 2 pages, folio. In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Simple substitution cipher, with numbers for letters and syllables. Signed, "par ordre avec 4 Clefs. 17 mars 1781. a 5 juillet 1783. Bourdier."

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous

Fulton, John. Translation into French of a letter to Col. John Allan, dated Le 26. Juillet 1780, with a "Memorandum" following, dated "A Machias Le 29. Juillet 1780." 2 pages, folio. With another piece, in French. 1 page, 4to.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Intelligence report on Halifax. The other piece is a report on Halifax, unsigned and undated, in French.

did.unittitle: Germain, Lord George. Copies, in French translation, of intercepted letters, the majority to Sir Henry Clinton. 6 pages., 4to. With two autograph notations by Rochambeau. [London, Feb. 7-March 7, 1781].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These copies consist of a letter to Clinton of Feb. 7, and another, dated March 7 (stated in The Writings of George Washington , ed. John C. Fitzpatrick to have been addressed to the British Peace Commissioners); another, dated Feb. 7, to Clinton; another, dated Feb. 28, to Clinton (note by Rochambeau states that this one was believed to be from the Duke of Newcastle); and a note concerning a letter to Benedict Arnold. Germain speaks with great confidence of conquering Maryland and Pennsylvania in these letters. They had been intercepted in Europe, and sent to Washington, Rochambeau, and Congress.

did.unittitle: Population. Statistical tables, in French, written in a secretary's hand, showing the population of the colonies and states at various times, 1750-1798. 1 page, folio. No place.

did.unittitle: Map Collection of the Comte de Rochambeau

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series V, Map Collection of the Comte de Rochambeau , is organized into ten subseries: War of the Austrian Succession, Cantons of Franche-Comté and Campaign against Mandrin, Seven Years' War, Inspector-General of the Infantry, Plan to Invade England, American Revolution, Command of Picardy and Artois, Command of Alsace, Journey to Switzerland, and Army of the North: Brabant Campaign.

did.unittitle: WAR OF THE AUSTRIAN SUCCESSION
Bohemian and Bavarian Campaigns

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This map is divided into 9 parts. There are 3 sections of 3 pieces each. Each map is uncolored, and 8 x 6 inches, folded.
These maps were cased together in a green board sleeve. See also: Oversize Sleeve Boxes, box 51.
1) Map tab inscription on part 1: Boheme le flle./Bôheme 1e flle haut/IK/251.
Notes to map, part 1: This is the first piece in the first section of 3 pieces (left to right). Linen-backed. Uncolored. 19 5/8 X 22 3/8 inches.
2) Map tab inscription on part 2: Boheme [rest illegible]/ Bôheme 2e flle haut
Notes to map, part 2: This is the second piece in the first section of 3 pieces (left to right). Linen-backed. Uncolored. 19 5/8 X 22 1/4 inches.
3) Map tab inscription on part 3: Boheme 3e [rest illegible] Boheme. 3e flle haut
Notes to map, part 3: This is the third piece in the first section of 3 pieces (left to right). Linen-backed. Uncolored. 19 5/8 X 22 5/16 inches.
4) Map tab inscription on part 4: Boheme 4 flle M/Boheme. 4e flle Milieu
Notes to map, part 4: This is the first piece in the second section of 3 pieces (left to right). Linen-backed. Uncolored. 19 1/4 x 22 7/16 inches.
5) Map tab inscription on part 5: Boheme 5e flle [rest illegible]/Boheme. 5e flle Milieu
Notes to map, part 5: This is the second piece in the second section of 3 pieces (left to right). Linen-backed. Uncolored. 19 1/4 x 22 5/16 inches.
6) Map tab inscription on part 6: [illegible]/Boheme. 6e flle Milieu
Notes to map, part 6: This is the third piece in the second section of 3 pieces (left to right). Linen-backed. Uncolored. 19 3/8 X 22 5/16 inches.
7) Map tab inscription on part 7: [illegible]/Boheme. 7e flle Bas.
Notes to map, part 7: This is the first piece in the third section of 3 pieces (left to right). Linen-backed. Uncolored. 19 7/16 X 22 7/16 inches.
8) Map tab inscription on part 8: [illegible]/Boheme. 8e flle Bas.
Notes to map, part 8: This is the second piece in the third section of 3 pieces (left to right). Linen-backed. Uncolored. 19 7/16 X 22 3/8 inches.
9) Map tab inscription on part 9: [illegible]/Boheme. 9e flle Bas.

Title and/or other information taken from map, part 9: CARTE/CHOROGRAPHIQUE/DE LA/BOHEME/Divisée en 12 Cercles/ Avec le Comté de Glatz/et le Territoire d'Egra/En neuf Feuilles égalles aux vingt cinq Petittea/de l'Illustre MULLER/DEDIÉE/A:S:AS.M. On 15 he has written "Communication en pierres qui tenait lieu/de parallelle." and at the bottom of the map "Na que le terrein qui entoure cette place/et les glacis sont sur le roc le plus sec et/qu'il n'y a pas Six pouces (?) de terre sur/toute la circonference."

1) Half topographical map of Hesse - Kassel Landgraviate by Carlet de la Rossierè, drawn for intelligence use for the campaign of Soubise (1758): "1e. Cartes à Madame la Comtesse de Rochambeau"
Map tab inscription: Hesse-Cassel

did.unittitle: Plan of Different Camps Occupied by Rochambeau's Army.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Campaign of 1781, June 10 - September 27, 1781. Series of 34 manuscript plans, entitled "Amerique Campagne 1781 Plans des differents camps occupes par L'Armee aux ordres de Mr. Le Comte De Rochambeau." 35 pages, folio, the maps in pen and ink and colors; color key on the title. Attributed to Louis-Alexandre and Charles-Louis Berthier.

It should be noted that a similar collection of plans, for the period of July 1 - Dec. 2, 1782, is in the Library of Congress (described in Phillips, List of Geographical Atlases , Vol. I, pp. 734-736).

did.unittitle: E 337 The Antilles. Paris: Le Rouge.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: There are thirteen maps, one folding, bound together in marbled boards. The front cover is inscribed: Cartes des antilles. The spine height measures 21 1/4 inches. The flyleaf is inscribed: E. The first map in this group (LES ANTILLES) is inscribed E/337. This volume is in a light blue cloth box case with a black leather label on spine lettered in gold: LE ROUGE/MAPS OF THE/ANTILLES, BERMUDA, AND/VIRGIN ISLANDS/1779. The spine height of the box-case is 23 1/8 inches.
The maps are bound as follows:
No. 1: LES ANTILLES/et la/GUAYANNE/Par la Rochette/1776/ Traduit de l'Anglais/A PARIS/Chéz Le Rouge Ingr. Geogr du Roi/Rue des Gds. Augustins/1779/Avec Privilége du Roi
Notes to No. 1: Inscribed E/337. Colored. 29 5/8 x 24 15/16 inches.

No. 2: LES/BERMUDES/Levées par Lampriere/Déterminées Astronomiquement/à Londres en 1775./Traduit de l'Anglois./ A PARIS/Chés Le Rouge Ingen. Géographe du Roi rue des grands Augustins/1779/Avec Privilege du Roi.
Notes to No. 2: Uncolored. 21 3/16 x 29 1/2 inches.

No. 3: LES ISLES TURQUES/d'aprés les Levées de 1753./par le Sloop l'Aigle et l'Emeraude/par ordre du Gouverneur de St. Domingue/corrigées sur les Observations de Ed: Hawke/ faites en 1770. dans le Shooner Royal./Publié a Londres en 1775./Traduit A PARIS/Chez le Rouge en 1779.
Notes to No. 3: Uncolored. 21 1/8 x 15 5/8 inches.
No. 4: LES VIERGES,/Levées/PAR LES ANGLAIS,/et/PAR LES DANNOIS,/Traduit de l'Anglais./A PARIS,/Chez le Sr. Le Rouge, rue des Grands Augustins,/1779.
Notes to No. 4: Colored. 21 3/16 x 29 5/8 inches.

No. 5: ISLE/ST CHRISTOPHE/OU/ST KITTS/Levé/Par Ant: Ravell Chevalier/Arpenteur Général/des Isles de St. Christophe, Nevis et Montserrat,/Par Jefferys en 1775,/Traduit de l'Anglais./A PARIS./Par le Rouge Ingr Geographe du Roi/rue des Grands Augustins/1779./avec Privilege du Roi.
Notes to No. 5: Uncolored. 21 1/4 x 29 1/2 inches.
No 6: ANTIGUE,/Levée/par/Robert Baker,/Arpenteur Général de l'Isle./Traduit de l'Anglais./A PARIS/Chez le Rouge rue des Gds. Augustins/1779./avec Privilege du Roi.
Notes to No. 6: Uncolored. 21 3/16 x 29 1/2, inches.

No. 7: STE LUCIE/D'après les Plans levés par les Anglois/ lors qu'ils la possedoient./Par Jefferys en 1775./Traduit de l'Anglois/A PARIS/Par le Rouge, Rue des grands Augustins./1779/Avec Privilege du Roi.
Notes to No. 7: Inscribed: St lucie Uncolored. 29 1/2 x 21 3/16 inches.
No. 8: LA BARBADE/Levée/par G: Mayo./Gravée par Jefferys/A PARIS/Chez le Rouge rue des grands Augustins./1779.
Notes to No. 8: Uncolored. 29 1/2 x 21 3/16 inches.
No. 9: BEQUIA/OU/BECOUYA,/la plus Septentrionale/des/ GRANADILLES,/Leve en 1763.
Notes to No. 9: Uncolored. 15 5/8 x 21 1/8, inches.
No. 10: TABAGO/Dressé sur des Arpentages nouveaux/Par JEFFERYS en 1775./Traduit de l'Anglois./A PARIS./Par le ROUGE Ingenieur Geographe du Roi; Rue des grands Augustins./avec Privilege du Roi 1779.
Notes to No. 10: Uncolored. 21 1/8 x 29 5/8 inches.
No. 11: Curaçao/Tiré/des Originaux Hollandois/de Van Keulen/Dressé sur les dernieres Observations/A PARIS Traduit de l'Anglais/Chez le Rouge rue des Gds. Augustins/ 1779.
Notes to No. 11: Uncolored. 21 1/8 x 29 1/2 inches.

No. 12: RUATAN OU RATTAN/LEVÉ/PAR HENRY BARNSLEY LIEUTENANT/Augmenté/Par JEFFERYS en 1775./Traduit de l'Anglais./A PARIS/Chés LE ROUGE Ingr Géographe Ordre du Roi, Rue des Gds. Augustins/1779./avec Privilege du Roi.
Notes to No. 12: Uncolored. 21 1/8 x 29 3/4 inches.

No. 13: LA MARTINIQUE/par les Ingenieurs Anglais/lorsqu'ils en étoient possesseurs/par Jefferys 1775./A PARIS/Chez le Rouge Ingr Géographe du Roi/Rue des Grands Augustins./ 1779./avec Privilege du Roi.
Notes to No. 13: Uncolored. 21 1/8 x 29 3/8 inches.

did.unittitle: Map Collection of the Vicomte de Rochambeau

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VI, Map Collection of the Vicomte de Rochambeau , is organized into eight subseries: American Islands, Italian Campaign and Command of Liguria, Prisoner in England, Central European Campaigns, French and European Campaigns, Spanish and Portuguese Campaigns, Russian Campaign, German Campaign.

did.unittitle: IK 321 Cary's New Map of England and Wales. London: John Cary.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Atlas in blue boards. Front and back covers are both loose from spine but not completely detached. The remnants of a paper label appear on spine. It is inscribed but illegible now since so much of it is missing. There is a page of manuscript (a list of other miscellaneous volumes) inserted loosely in the volume.
Inscribed inside front cover: Dtn. Rochambeau/[and] IK/321. appears on back of title page

Title page reads: CARY's/NEW MAP/of/ENGLAND AND WALES,/ WITH PART OF/SCOTLAND./ON WHICH ARE CAREFULLY LAID DOWN/ All the Direct and Principal Cross Roads, the Course of the Rivers/AND/NAVIGABLE CANALS,/Cities, Market and Borough Towns, Parishes, and most considerable Hamlets, Parks, Forests &c. &c./Delineated from Actual Surveys; and materially assisted/FROM/AUTHENTIC DOCUMENTS/Liberally supplied by the Right Honourable the/POST MASTERS GENERAL/ LONDON:/Publish'd June 11th 1794 by J. Cary, Engraver & Map-seller, No. 181 Strand. [There is also a dedication page from John Cary to The Right Honourable Philip, Earl of Chesterfield and Baron Stanhope... There is also a page of EXPLANATIONS on which the following appears: Published by J. Cary, June 11, 1794. LIST OF PLACES and LIST OF SUBSCRIBERS both appear at the back of the Atlas.]
Notes: Colored and uncolored. 13 3/8 x 10 1/2 inches.

TAFEL/zur Zusamensetzung der Carte von Russland, von Danielow./[and] TABLEAU D'ASSEMBLAGE/à la Carte de la Russie,/par/DANIELOW./[and] Publiée et se trouve/à Vienne chez T. Mollo. This map is Uncolored and measures 9 15/16 x 8 1/2 inches.

Title and/or other information taken from map, part 1: KARTE DES EUROPAISES/und eines/? des asiatis ch=russischen Reichs/nach den neuesten astronomischen Ortsbestimungen, den grossen Atlas und andern Karten/des russisch=Kaiser: Karten=Depots verfasst; in Gouverements eingetheilt, die Grentzen nach/den letzten Friedenschlüssen berichtiget, dann die Post=und andere Hauptstrassen mit/Bemerkung der Ortsentfernungen eingetragen/von/JWAN DANIELOW./[and] CARTE DE LA PARTIE EUROPEENE ET ASIATIQUE de/L'Empire de Russie/avec l'indication des chemins et routes de Postes, ainsi que des nouvelles démarcations, et de la/répartition actuelle en gouvernements. Redigée d'après le grand Atlas et d'autres Cartes du/Dépot géographique Imperial de St. Pétersbourg/Publiée et se trouve à Vienne chez T. Mollo. 1812.

Green cardboard box with top opening. Inscribed on sleeve: IK/369. Inscribed on label laid down on spine of sleeve: Amerique/Septentrionalle/Nelle. angleterre/4 Feuilles/Rhode Island/2. Feuilles/New Jersey. Sleeve measures 8 x 5 3/4 x 2 inches.

Green cardboard box with top opening. Inscribed on sleeve: IK/371. Inscribed on label laid down on spine of sleeve: Province de New York/carte generalle/Province de New york/4 Feuilles/Pensilvanie/3 Feuilles/Baye De la Delaware/Virginie et Maryland/2 Feuilles. The sleeve measures 8 x 5 5/8 x 2 5/8 inches.
IK 370 Maps of the Carolinas.

Green cardboard box with top opening. Inscribed on sleeve: IK/370. Inscribed on label laid down on spine of sleeve: Caroline Septe. et Merle./4 Feuilles/Caroline et georgie/4 Feuilles/Cotes Des Carolines/ou Environs De/Charles town/ La Floride et Les/Isles Bahama/2 Feuilles. The sleeve measures 8 x 5 1/2 x 3 5/8 inches.
IK 32 Dunkerque, Calais, Boulogne, St. Omer by Cassini. Paris: Vignon Marchand.

Mottled paper box case (the very top of the upper section is missing, and the very bottom of the lower section is missing). Inscribed on the outside of the case: IK/32. There is a label laid down on the front of the upper part of the case that is inscribed: Cassini/Cartes de France/en feuilles/1 Dunkerque/2 Pas de Calais/3 Boulogne/ 4 St. Omer/Paris/1744-93. There is a leather label on the spine that is lettered in gold: CARTES/DE/FRANCE. There is also a small part of a printed map (showing Boulogne, etc) laid down on spine beneath leather label. Box case measures: 8 5/8 x 6 x 2 1/4 inches.
